This allows sharing of role files from a single location.
It will be used for sharing common tasks of many roles, like
the mq, the dabatase, or service setup.

Without this patch, roles implementing the same kind of files
would eventually drift and be different.

This is a problem as this increases the maintenance burden.

This patch solves the problem by allowing a proposal bot to
update the files in the roles, should they exist.

commit_message:
Add mq_setup common task file

This patch adds the common task file for the mq setup tasks
which will be replicated by the proposal bot between the roles.

It also updates the script that's useful for manual sync to
accommodate the ability to sync the task file. Some documentation
is also added.

This allows sharing of role files from a single location.
It will be used for sharing common tasks of many roles, like
the mq, the dabatase, or service setup.

Without this patch, roles implementing the same kind of files
would eventually drift and be different. This is a problem as
this increases the maintenance burden.

Relates-To: https://review.openstack.org/580696
Co-Authored-By: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>
Change-Id: Ib564450eb1f3d63bb5fdd3763046dd57df519d28

[{'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-03-16 00:52:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-03-16 01:01:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-16 10:30:52.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/s to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-03-16 14:24:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-03-16 19:58:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-03-16 19:59:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-20 08:40:11.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/s to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-20 11:00:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I still have to dive deeper into the project itself, but at first glance my main concern would be around scope and potential for adoption.

The project clearly fits in the openstack-operations bucket of the OpenStack map (probably under the "Billing / Business logic" subcategory, next to CloudKitty), so I think it's overall "in scope" for addition.

As far as features are concerned, is it limited to business logic tasks, or is it more of a generally-applicable way to create an API where the existing projects are not providing it ? If the latter, how much of its functionality should not be baked in existing projects instead ? Will such a framework drive more interoperability, or create more differences between deployments ?

Basically, by making it official we are encouraging its usage. So is it a pattern we want to encourage or not ? Do we expect that framework to be adopted a lot (is there a need, is this a gap?)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-03-20 11:54:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> As far as features are concerned, is it limited to business logic
> tasks, or is it more of a generally-applicable way to create an API
> where the existing projects are not providing it ? If the latter,
> how much of its functionality should not be baked in existing
> projects instead ? Will such a framework drive more
> interoperability, or create more differences between deployments ?

The truth is, Adjutant is not really at all limited to 'business-logic'. The first ever task we got working fully, because it was simply, was password reset. I'm not really sure you'd call that business logic. We had a customer who kept forgetting their password and we got sick of manually having to do it, and it's a thing that most clouds have to deal with. Most clouds write their own reset process. So we did too, except we added it to a service we thought others could use, thus that little operations task that doesn't really fit anywhere in OpenStack was covered. Or we wanted a better way to allow users to invite others to their projects, but Keystone didn't give us the policy granularity we needed, nor did it make sense for Keystone to send out invite emails.
Those are the kind of things that this service is great for. Things that don't really fit anywhere, but need to exist and if we don't write a service upstream for them, we end up with entirely different versions of it on each cloud.

So the goal, is try and make as many useful things like that we can all share in the core project, with enough pieces for building on top of, so our clouds start looking more and more alike. And when we need to, we can also augment those with extra logic specific to our clouds. There will always be differences, but the hope with something like this service is that the effort to solve those small user or admin interactions can be shared, and we can limit the differences a bit.

Then again Adjutant is fairly flexible, and it gives cloud providers a way to potentially add some wrapper logic or better UX around other APIs in a way that may not entirely make sense in those places. For example we made a plugin for helping up manage MFA on our cloud:
https://github.com/catalyst-cloud/adjutant-mfa

Maybe some of that logic will eventually end up in keystone, maybe we'll always prefer to wrap the logic ourselves so we can control the logic and UX.

A large part as to why the Adjutant project guide-lines now exist is trying to make it clear that Adjutant should be a place of last resort for something that makes better sense in another project, or ONLY as a stop gap measure that allows cloud providers through non-core plugins to add the missing API while another project implements it properly:
http://adjutant.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide-lines.html

> Basically, by making it official we are encouraging its usage. So
> is it a pattern we want to encourage or not ? Do we expect that
> framework to be adopted a lot (is there a need, is this a gap?)

It entirely depends on the cloud. We do kind of use Adjutant in weird ways, and intend to expand on that. One of the next Catalyst specific plugins we are doing is one that builds tasks around updating and managing customer billing information. Adjutant gives us an easy way to integrate with keystone auth, but allow small little actions to external systems. As silly as it sounds, it's almost a way of trying to encourage slightly less hacky solutions for what ultimately are hacky solutions that most clouds build.

Should we encourage that? Maybe? Better in some cases that than cloud providers always having to build their own systems for managing stuff like that. Yes that logic will always be slightly different per cloud, but this might give them the building blocks to solve it faster and integrate it better into OpenStack."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-20 16:25:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-20 16:44:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-03-20 16:44:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-03-20 16:59:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-21 14:31:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-21 15:40:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-21 16:44:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-03-21 22:53:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

> Is the point for the deployer to be able to create APIs to implement their own
> business logic in a way that the cloud user can trigger, so that the deployer
> only has to run 1 service, rather than a bunch of micro-services, to extend
> their cloud? Or are the APIs likely to be triggered by events other than direct
> user invocation (like by consuming a notification from another service)?

The former. A deployer can make an Adjutant API that is triggered by something else that does read notifications if they want, but Adjutant itself will not be looking at notifications from other systems, you need to trigger it directly.

> What sort of interoperability expectations are there for Adjutant? Is there any
> part of its API that is considered "standard" across clouds? It sounds like
> each API is completely up to the deployer to specify. If the problem space is
> "managing user accounts" I could see the Adjutant team defining a common set of
> APIs where the *implementation* is deployment specific (or at least easy to
> customize for a deployment). It's not clear that's what you're trying to
> build, though.

We have already, and will be keep adding some common APIs that should be useful to any cloud, but it is up to the deployer as to which ones they enabled. Ideally we want to make those as useful as possible so they choose to enable them, and make them easy enough to add some extra business logic to while still making them act in a generic enough way.

An example, Adjutant has a set of task APIs around managing quotas between size groups (small, medium, large). We are using in our production environment the pure version of that as in the core codebase. But soon we'll be adding an extra action to that workflow that checks in our ERP system if a customer has ever paid an invoice, and if they have any overdue ones. If the answer is favourable, the extra action marks the task as a whole safe to auto approve, otherwise it says no, and requires an admin to be notified to decide if that quota change is valid.

Ideally those kind of augmentations is what we want to encourage. Useful core feature, augmented to be cloud specific without changing how it actually works or us triggered by a user.

But then things like password resets, and likely user invitations are things that also will be used by more than one cloud, and often without augmentation. The more unique examples I'm giving you that can be done with the plugins are more extreme cases, so you're aware of the full spectrum of what 'might' occur, but on average we hope that the core task APIs are used as is, or with minor augmentations.

On top of that we want to eventually also make the python libraries that talk to Adjutant be able to discover what APIs and tasks have been defined by the deployer, and how those APIs act, so even if the tasks are different on each cloud, the tools help you use them and the service itself provides powerful feature discovery (but that's future work).

And trust me I fully understand your confusion, and one of the main outcomes I expect out of this process is for us to define what Adjutant is as best as we can to make it clearer as to what it should/shouldn't be used for. If that means I need to add more to our own docs to do so I shall.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-03-22 08:59:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi, I have maybe a very dummy question (sorry, I didn't thoroughly read all the docs). Can you please give a concrete scenario of how Adjutant can be used? Something like: using Adjutant, we can do this (step 1), that (step 2) and so on and achieve this.

At this point I'm having a hard time trying to understand what exactly we can do with Adjutant. The word "workflow" widely used in the docs and by yourself also concerns me for the obvious seeming overlapping with Mistral.'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-03-22 11:29:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> The word "workflow" widely used in
 > the docs and by yourself also concerns me for the obvious seeming
 > overlapping with Mistral.

Indeed, I believe that could be confusing for users. I feel like Adjutant isn't a workflow service (at least, not how Mistral sees being a workflow service). It feels more like an "API service" or "app service" (I can't think of a good name), somewhere you can put some Python code and have it exposed via an API etc.

I think the biggest distinction is that you don't add "workflows" to it via the API. Nova is a compute service and you start servers via the API, heat is orchestration and you add templates via the api etc. but iiuc Adjutant is something that operators need to setup and manage. The API is just for accessing whatever is installed. I can't think of any other OpenStack services that work this way, but there is probably an obvious example I am missing.'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-03-22 11:40:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Interestingly, TripleO uses Mistral in a way that matches some of your use case.  We add features we need that the other OpenStack projects don't want to include/support.

For example, ironic-inspector does a great job of introspection, but it doesn't have support for introspection a batch of nodes and automatically retrying etc. on failure. We have a number of Mistral workflows that automate and manage this process.

It is also interesting to note that the workflows are often described as the TripleO API. Something I am not keen on, but it does make sense in a way. tripleoclient and tripleo-ui use these workflows to interact with TripleO.

This approach don't have a REST interface for these workflows (other than via Mistral's API) and we don't have any automatic UI integration (tripleo has a custom UI). Otherwise the end result feels like it will be quite similar."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-03-23 00:15:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Hi, I have maybe a very dummy question (sorry, I didn't thoroughly
> read all the docs). Can you please give a concrete scenario of how
> Adjutant can be used? Something like: using Adjutant, we can do
> this (step 1), that (step 2) and so on and achieve this.

From a user perspective, some of the default task APIs let you reset your password by sending a token to your email. Users can then also invite other users and manage their roles in a fashion that is more limited than the raw Keystone API underneath. A deployer can also configure and augment the signup Task API which lets prospective users (or the cloud website) accept signup requests that will process the whole new customer setup process. The core Adjutant API lets tokens generated by tasks be submitted to continue a task, which in the reset password case lets you submit a new password. 

It's a deployer controlled service to expose Micro APIs that don't have a place anywhere else, that underneath (in the service internals) are actually non-user defined workflows.

> > The word "workflow" widely used in
> > the docs and by yourself also concerns me for the obvious seeming
> > overlapping with Mistral.
>
> Indeed, I believe that could be confusing for users. I feel like
> Adjutant isn't a workflow service (at least, not how Mistral sees
> being a workflow service). It feels more like an "API service" or
> "app service" (I can't think of a good name), somewhere you can put
> some Python code and have it exposed via an API etc.
>
> I think the biggest distinction is that you don't add "workflows"
> to it via the API. Nova is a compute service and you start servers
> via the API, heat is orchestration and you add templates via the
> api etc. but iiuc Adjutant is something that operators need to
> setup and manage. The API is just for accessing whatever is
> installed. I can't think of any other OpenStack services that work
> this way, but there is probably an obvious example I am missing.

Dougal is right, Adjutant is not a workflow service. A user cannot make their own workflow, the workflow system will always be entirely internal as to how the logic is processed. What Adjutant does is expose APIs that the deployer wants which use that internal workflow to achieve some purpose. The sole reason the internals are workflow based (and will expand a lot more on that front) is because that means the logic we want to write isn't entirely too limited, and often has to be multi step.

There really isn't a good name for what it is... It's a framework for building Micro APIs on your cloud that don't have a home, or need some extra logic layers, and it happens to use an internal workflow system to do that. It's a service mostly to do actions on behalf of the cloud admins for users, hence the reason behind the name. You make APIs you can delegate user requests to for that problem you'd otherwise need to do manually.

That's why I'm mostly calling it the Operations Logic service because that's about as close to describing it as I got. Maybe focus on the Mirco API concept and base a service type off that? Since that's a term I want to use more to describe what exactly those APIs are.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-23 21:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Dougal is right, Adjutant is not a workflow service. A user cannot
 > make their own workflow, the workflow system will always be

So it sounds like workflows are an (important) implementation detail but not a fundamental aspect of the APIs presented by Adjutant. That eliminates any concern I have with overlap with Mistral, which does present a general purpose Workflow-as-a-service API. I think we can stop talking about workflows because that just obfuscates things.

 > There really isn't a good name for what it is... It's a framework
 > for building Micro APIs on your cloud that don't have a home, or
 > need some extra logic layers, and it happens to use an internal
 > workflow system to do that. It's a service mostly to do actions on
 > behalf of the cloud admins for users, hence the reason behind the
 > name. You make APIs you can delegate user requests to for that
 > problem you'd otherwise need to do manually.
 > 
 > That's why I'm mostly calling it the Operations Logic service
 > because that's about as close to describing it as I got. Maybe
 > focus on the Mirco API concept and base a service type off that?
 > Since that's a term I want to use more to describe what exactly
 > those APIs are.

The remaining concerns I have then are about the scope and interoperability.

If Adjutant was pitched as an API service for tying OpenStack to existing deployer services (for account management, quotas, and maybe even those network configuration enforcement things you mentioned) and the APIs were *well defined* but the implementation details were deployer-specific (via drivers, or deployer scripts, or playbooks, or hooks, or whatever other mechanism), I would have no problem with adding Adjutant as a project.

But it sounds like the whole idea is to allow deployers to add whatever they want/need in a way that means the APIs are often going to be unique to the cloud. That approach makes Adjutant sound less like a component of a whole OpenStack cloud and more like an opportunity for a deployer to use an official project to add unofficial APIs that result in lock-in (whether it is intended that way or not, it seems like it's a likely outcome).

We used to have API extensions in several projects, and finally eliminated them because the community felt it was more important to ensure interoperability. So I have a real reluctance to add a project that is "all" extensions.

On the other hand, I think a service that sits in the middle, defining APIs for common integration operations and recognizing that every deployer is likely to be unique so allows for flexibility in the implementation, would be very valuable.

Do you think that the approach I'm describing, of having well-defined APIs for doing that integration, is something the Adjutant team could support and adapt to? It might mean slowing down a bit, to only add things when it's clear that multiple clouds are likely to need them. And it would mean approaching the API design to give reusability between clouds 
a higher priority than it might otherwise have, and deemphasizing the idea of deployers adding one-off APIs.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-03-23 21:16:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Maybe I'm missing something on the interoperability concerns. Or I just haven't digested some parts of this yet.

But this is a service/framework/whangdoodle specifically for operators to use to enable things for their deployment, and not as a "cloud API" that will be exposed for their end users to consume, right?

If that is the case, then I see no issues with differentiation, as I would expect nearly all cloud providers to have internal systems that help them manage their service provider systems each in their own unique and customized way.

Like I said, it's quite possible I am missing a key piece here, but from my understanding reading things so far, interoperability is not one of my concerns.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-23 21:36:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

As one example, the quotas page [1] says "The quota API will allow users to change their quota values". So it sounds like the APIs are meant to be consumed by cloud users.

Ah, that makes a little more sense. Thanks Doug.

I interpreted that as more operator automation. So rather than a customer needing to call up their cloud provider to give them a credit card number and ask them to increase their available resources, this would allow the operator to plumb that process into their system. I didn't take that as a direct API an end user would be calling, at least knowingly.

I would like some clarification on that from the Adjutant team though to validate that assumption."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-03-23 21:59:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Ah, that makes a little more sense. Thanks Doug.
 > 
 > I interpreted that as more operator automation. So rather than a
 > customer needing to call up their cloud provider to give them a
 > credit card number and ask them to increase their available
 > resources, this would allow the operator to plumb that process into
 > their system. I didn't take that as a direct API an end user would
 > be calling, at least knowingly.
 > 
 > I would like some clarification on that from the Adjutant team
 > though to validate that assumption.

Before I go back and answer some of Doug's questions, let me try and clarify this.

Most of the APIs Adjutant would expose would be consumed by users. Mostly through panels in Horizon, but the APIs will exist and ideally we want to write client tools that dynamically can change their functionality based on what the server itself is configured to have.

It's a means of automating what would normally be client > operator interactions. In our cloud, we're trying to get away from having to give our account managers and support staff as much Admin powers, so building lots of Adjutant APIs that handle most of their interactions for us, makes life easier. Also faster resolution time for users than waiting for a human to do it. Then we can also make some support only Adjutant APIs to wrap around some other normally admin APIs as well so again their interactions go through Adjutant for safety rather than to the service itself. That way we have a full history of the actions in Adjutant.

So in a way, the service is for both."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-03-23 22:55:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> The remaining concerns I have then are about the scope and
> interoperability.
> 
> If Adjutant was pitched as an API service for tying OpenStack to
> existing deployer services (for account management, quotas, and
> maybe even those network configuration enforcement things you
> mentioned) and the APIs were *well defined* but the implementation
> details were deployer-specific (via drivers, or deployer scripts,
> or playbooks, or hooks, or whatever other mechanism), I would have
> no problem with adding Adjutant as a project.

We can do some of that. The goal of the core features in Adjutant itself will be things like that. We can explicitly include that in our mission and figure out with the various cloud deployers what such a set of APIs might look like. We can then provide a default implementation and provide safe ways to extend those and tools to talk to those APIs.

> But it sounds like the whole idea is to allow deployers to add
> whatever they want/need in a way that means the APIs are often
> going to be unique to the cloud. That approach makes Adjutant sound
> less like a component of a whole OpenStack cloud and more like an
> opportunity for a deployer to use an official project to add
> unofficial APIs that result in lock-in (whether it is intended that
> way or not, it seems like it's a likely outcome).
> 
> We used to have API extensions in several projects, and finally
> eliminated them because the community felt it was more important to
> ensure interoperability. So I have a real reluctance to add a
> project that is "all" extensions.
> 
> On the other hand, I think a service that sits in the middle,
> defining APIs for common integration operations and recognizing
> that every deployer is likely to be unique so allows for
> flexibility in the implementation, would be very valuable.
> 
> Do you think that the approach I'm describing, of having
> well-defined APIs for doing that integration, is something the
> Adjutant team could support and adapt to? It might mean slowing
> down a bit, to only add things when it's clear that multiple clouds
> are likely to need them. And it would mean approaching the API
> design to give reusability between clouds
> a higher priority than it might otherwise have, and deemphasizing
> the idea of deployers adding one-off APIs.

To continue on with the above, core Adjutant will always include the kind of APIs you describe, but it will still always be up to the deployer as to which of those they turn on.

The plugins though, aren't going away. Catalyst uses them, and the crux of that matter is that cloud providers will write these kind of APIs somewhere regardless of whether OpenStack supports extensions. The problem is, they write it themselves, in house, and likely don't always integrate it as well into OpenStack, not to mention they write it in languages that they might know, but not all OpenStack devs do so we can't always help them. Adjutant in those cases serves as a stop gap to give them a better alternative to doing it themselves. We'd give them some sensible auth handled by Keystone, provide them tools to talk to OpenStack through well supported libraries and with a hopefully growing set of common utils for building these Micro APIs on top of the internal workflow. We encourage them not to resort to plugins unless absolutely required, but at least we can guide them a bit if they do. That already is a worthwhile benefit even if it doesn't help interop directly, because we can at least then work with those clouds to ask why they need entirely custom APIs, and encourage consistent practices through Adjutant's framework.

For example, we'll be using plugins in Adjutant to let customers manage their billing information, update their credit card in our system, etc. This doesn't have a place anywhere right now in OpenStack, but we need to use Keystone auth to know who to link those changes too. Sure down the line I'd love for us to define some generic template APIs for stuff like this which other clouds can use so we all do it in similar ways, but this will only ever really be used via Horizon so interoperability isn't a worry for me. We also use a very heavily augmented version of the core signup API for our signup process, but that only ever gets touched by our website.

Those are ideally what I expect the plugins to be used for or augmentations to the core features like the one I described in a previous response that just marks a task as needing approval if there are unpaid invoices but doesn't alter the API. 

My plan for Adjutant this year was to expand on the core service with a series of needed internal refactors and splitting of logic. Then start looking at what the 'core' default Micro APIs should be. Potentially start looking at splitting that work into 'core' for what all clouds could use, and then officially supported plugins for extra features that may be useful. Anything that the Adjutant team officially supports should be generic and useful to any cloud, and we'd provide help for certain kinds of augmentations, discourage others, and try and make it clear that entirely custom APIs are a last resort or should be cloud specific for a good reason.

Adjutant's admin APIs will be fixed and well defined (check task status, cancel a task, submit a token, etc), but the Micro APIs (Aux APIs? configured APIs? I need a better term...) will always be entirely configurable. That said I do need a better term for these APIs. We used to call them TaskViews when we thought 1 Task meant 1 API, but now that we do 1 Task:1-3 APIs we need to rethink the terminology as we refactor those internals.

Sorry for the tangents, but I hope that at least sort of gets across what we're trying to do. I fully understand your concerns about interoperability and I want to find a good middle ground that doesn't entirely limit us, but doesn't encourage too much madness.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-03-28 12:01:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(There are questions within pointed tangentially at both the TC and
at Adjutant but if this feels too much like a wall of text, feel
free to think of questions as rhetorical.)

Every time we have discussions about adding a project as an official
member of the gang, I feel a bit at sea. That is, I don't have
sufficient awareness of a set of goals that we're striving to reach
and rules that we hope to follow. That awareness is required to do
this part of the job effectively. It may very well be that the goals
and rules do exist, but either I'm ignorant or they are so fungible
as to not matter. I'm not sure.

Thus, we come to these things and at least I start from sort of
first principles and questions that themselves lead to more
questions:

* Do the people and point of the project seem useful (independent of
  the question "useful to whom?")?
* Do they overlap with other projects?
* Should overlap with other projects be of any concern? (It should
  not, not if we expect to evolve.)
* Does this project advance the goals of OpenStack?
* Oh wait, what are the goals of OpenStack?
* What does this project gain by being official?
* What does this project lose by being official?
* Is growth (in OpenStack) good or bad?

And each time we sort of talk around these things, but it never
feels like it sticks. I don't know why that is. It could be as
simple as because I (or someone else) never agree[s], so don't let
any decisions settle.

This (not agreeing) is very possible because:

* It sometimes feels like OpenStack is a cloister, gently walled off
  from the rest of the world, and that's fundamentally a bad thing™
  and we should be dissolving those walls (by having close friends
  on the outside) rather than bringing people into the keep.

* The more official projects there are, the more dilute the "brand"
  which is OpenStack may become. Having lots of official projects
  feels like a declaration of unbounded-ness and an acceptance that
  there is no product which is OpenStack. That's not necessarily a
  bad thing, but it's weird.

* There's an argument to be made that we shouldn't make anything
  official until a diverse collection of OpenStack users are using
  it. That is, let popularity and demonstrated value drive
  officialness rather than hoping that officialness will enable
  value and popularity.

I think this latter point is where most of my current feelings about
Adjutant sit. This:

"...the crux of that matter is that cloud providers
will write these kind of APIs somewhere regardless of whether
OpenStack supports extensions. The problem is, they write it
themselves, in house, and likely don't always integrate it as well
into OpenStack, not to mention they write it in languages that they
might know, but not all OpenStack devs do so we can't always help
them. Adjutant in those cases serves as a stop gap to give them a
better alternative to doing it themselves."

is compelling and _exactly_ what we hope for in an open source world
and the Catalyst people have demonstrated admirably that they can be
"out there" in that world, making things happen. They are already
healthy.

How does governance by the TC help them? How do the rules which we
will want to apply (such a being very concerned about
interoperability) help the cloud operators who simply want to create
a better user experience for their customer work flows, above and
beyond the (very) limited set that an un-doctored horizon provides?

How does the OpenStack cloister and heavy (to some) process help
cloud operators who want to use Adjutant to help them make
customizations in their environment?

How does membership of Adjutant in OpenStack Official Projects™
(instead of alternatives such as being an independent open source
project that happens to work with OpenStack) help OpenStack?
Adjutant? Operators? If we have solid answers to these questions
then we can probably make a straightforward decision that feels
correct.

If it is simply so there's somewhere for the IP to have a legal
home, that's cool. But if that's the case then "good with the four
opens" and "one of us" ought to be enough, except for the way it
impacts much of what's been said above. And thus the boat goes out
to sea...

At the moment I remain inclined to accept simply because Adjutant
seems pretty useful for a segment of the population and the rules
for good behavior are being followed. And they are certainly no less
valuable or "good" than some existing official projects.

But that seems a pretty weak set of criteria.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-03-28 13:05:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote-1

[I'll return later today to cdent's existential questions, it requires a bit more thought on my part...]

First off, it totally isn't clear to me what the "micro-APIs" are, REST APIs exposed to cloud ops?  to cloud consumers?  Or as I'm learning from conversation, this may be just a web interface builder?

Because if it is just a web interface builder, it deserves the same consideration as Horizon does re being part of OpenStack.  Some thought we shouldn't have gotten into the web UI business at all, but of course we had to have one even if many ops replace it.

If Adjutant exposes REST APIs (what exactly is a micro API?) then we have a totally different story.  Because today interoperability is only concerned with REST APIs.

Is this an accurate summation of Adjutant?

"Shade/SDK-as-a-Service" + deployer scripting -> Horizon panels

In other words, it overlaps more with Oaktree than anything else, exchanging the HTTP/2+proto bufs for a Django web front-end and non-predictable behaviour.

But it appears to actually be both.  and honestly I do not have a lot of sympathy for a project that encourages random non-interoperable functionality being exposed to users.  Interoperability is important to us and the work we have today is already greatly limited in scope due to a few particular public clouds that have not and will not fully embrace the OpenStack APIs. We need to expand the interoperability standards not encourage more vendor lock-in.

I totally understand why cloud operators want something like this, they generally do not care about interoperability beyond whatever stick is used to push them toward the trademark carrot.

But as someone heavily invested in the cloud consuming client world I can not support a further fragmentation of our ecosystem.

https://xkcd.com/927/'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-03-28 15:38:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I am pondering Dean's and the rest of Chris's thoughts, but I have a quick point on the following:

> How does membership of Adjutant in OpenStack Official Projects™
> (instead of alternatives such as being an independent open source
> project that happens to work with OpenStack) help OpenStack?
> Adjutant? Operators? If we have solid answers to these questions
> then we can probably make a straightforward decision that feels
> correct.

I do not want to put words in the Adjuncts team's mouths but from the viewpoint of a project (that ultimately failed):

Adjunct:

In a word they gain discoverability.

e.g. :

* Being able to publish to docs.o.o
* Being able to include docs in the install guide
* Inclusion in the project navigator and future constellations
* Operating System packaging
* PTG / Forum space

Operators:

* They gain the ability to find adjunct
* As an official project the chances of being included in deployment tooling like kolla / osa / puppet / etc dramatically increases - making installation much easier
* OS Packaging (may not be a big deal for public cloud scale installations, but for medium enterprises running internal clouds things like sign up, quota requests, password resets all help smaller operators, and being able to `<package manager> install adjunct` is a good thing for them)"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-29 12:32:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I understand cdent's doubts when it comes to the rules we should follow to consider new projects. Those rules are constantly evolving, and not only do we apply them, we also define them, which always puts us in an uncomfortable position.

As a data point, here is a set of questions I ask myself when considering new projects today:

1. Is the project developed in an open, collaborative manner (or very likely to adopt it once approved)? Are they aligned with our principles? That is pretty well described in our requirements.

2. Is the project benefiting from being set up as an open collaborative playground? Developing on a level playing field under the governance of an upper body is really a trade-off, and not for every situation. If the project is unlikely to attract a diverse affiliation, or is strongly opinionated, it's probably better for everyone not to be part of it.

3. Is there a "product fit" ? We have been shy in the past defining what is "OpenStack" and what is beyond OpenStack (consuming OpenStack, deploying OpenStack, reusing OpenStack components). We used to hide that behind the "is it helping with the mission" vague question. And that hurt us, by making OpenStack going everywhere we alienated other communities working on adjacent technologies. Working on the map really helped me visualize boundaries / buckets from a "product" consumer perspective, and I think when something does not fit inside one of those buckets (or pulls one of those buckets in a weird direction) it's part of our job to say no.

4. Is OpenStack-the-framework better with that project in, or better with that project out ? Sometimes the drawbacks of making something a part of OpenStack outweighs the benefits. For example, every project we add is a trade-off between making functionality available and making interoperability more difficult. Is that extra functionality worth it ?

In the Adjutant case, they are definitely aligned with the way we do things, and there is a good product fit (part of the openstack-operators bucket). I'm less convinced they would benefit from being set up as a level playing field, and more importantly I'm concerned that OpenStack-the-framework will be lot less interoperable with that project in than with this project out.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-04-03 20:46:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-04-04 05:40:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Just back from the Easter weekend, there is a lot to respond to, so apologies ahead of time for a long response as I try and address all the comments since.

@ChrisDent Responses to some of your points below (tried to address the most relevant ones).

> * The more official projects there are, the more dilute the "brand"
> which is OpenStack may become. Having lots of official projects
> feels like a declaration of unbounded-ness and an acceptance that
> there is no product which is OpenStack. That's not necessarily a
> bad thing, but it's weird.

But is there really an "OpenStack" product? Maybe back when it was just one project mostly all under the Nova codebase back in the day. OpenStack is an ecosystem, isn't it? At which point having lots of pieces that work together becomes a strength as to how much that ecosystem thrives.

> * There's an argument to be made that we shouldn't make anything
> official until a diverse collection of OpenStack users are using
> it. That is, let popularity and demonstrated value drive
> officialness rather than hoping that officialness will enable
> value and popularity.

Has OpenStack ever done that? Qinling (also started at Catalyst) was recently added and no one is using that in production. :P

Then also from memory (and I'm a bit bias here) Cloudkitty was added despite not really being used much at all, and still not being used much at all. We were involved with CloudKitty for a bit, but ended up staying with our in house project Distil because migrating wasn't going to be easy, not that Distil was much better.

Maybe what we instead need is a process where we check the health of projects and potentially retire them if no traction or uptake has occurred or we don't block that space for potentially better projects. That then means we can allow projects that seem to fill the role at the time into the fold so their have a chance to grow with help from the Official status. But how to solve this problem is beyond the scope of this discussion.

> How does governance by the TC help them? How do the rules which we
> will want to apply (such a being very concerned about
> interoperability) help the cloud operators who simply want to
> create
> a better user experience for their customer work flows, above and
> beyond the (very) limited set that an un-doctored horizon provides?

TC doesn't really help us directly, as is we can break the API, change the service, and do all kinds of things without worry. That is a huge advantage in the short term, and until v1.0.0 we likely will break things, but in the long term that benefits only us. As silly as it sounds by working with the TC we get some constraints that help us make the service better for everyone, not just Catalyst.

> How does the OpenStack cloister and heavy (to some) process help
> cloud operators who want to use Adjutant to help them make
> customizations in their environment?

Ideally, through the plugins. We make Adjutant itself useful as is, through its core features and officially supported plugins, but make it flexible enough so a deployer can tweak it as needed ideally in ways that maintain the core functions of that micro-APIs in question.

> How does membership of Adjutant in OpenStack Official Projects™
> (instead of alternatives such as being an independent open source
> project that happens to work with OpenStack) help OpenStack?
> Adjutant? Operators? If we have solid answers to these questions
> then we can probably make a straightforward decision that feels
> correct.

First and foremost, official status brings visibility. It potentially helps us not carry the burden of development alone, and gives us constraints that in a way are quite useful to helping maintain and build a service that is meant to be part of such an ecosystem. It helps operators because we have to adhere to the constraints we end up with through the TC as they will be less likely to hit breaking changes to the service/APIs. OpenStack is helped because Adjutant fills a niche that is needed but no good solution exists for. Not that Adjutant is a good solution, Adjutant is just one of the least awful solutions to a truly miserable problem.


@DeanTroyer 

> First off, it totally isn't clear to me what the "micro-APIs" are,
> REST APIs exposed to cloud ops?  to cloud consumers?  Or as I'm
> learning from conversation, this may be just a web interface
> builder?

It does no web interface building at all. We have a horizon plugin, which will contain panels for 'core' features, but any custom plugins need to also have their own custom horizon panels just like everyone else. In fact at Catalyst we have a second plugin for horizon that has custom panels for one of our Adjutant customisations. A web interface builder is not on the roadmap. I won't discount the option of dynamic gui in future once we have better declaration of Tasks/APIs just like we'd want to do with a dynamic client, but no such plan exists.

> If Adjutant exposes REST APIs (what exactly is a micro API?) then
> we have a totally different story.  Because today interoperability
> is only concerned with REST APIs.

Adjutant exposes REST APIs that are compatible with Keystone Auth via keystonemiddleware. Some of these APIs are the service admin APIs (approve a task, cancel a task, reissue a task token, etc), and those will always be part of the service in some backwards compatible fashion and are admin specific for the most part, or limited by project scope. The "micro-APIs" are additional configurable REST APIs that expose some of the defined internal workflows. These are the actual useful bits from a user perspective. Core Adjutant would focus on useful management and admin tasks which users can trigger themselves and that should be useful to many clouds. These 'mirco-APIs' once established would be backwards compatible as in the core codebase, but turned on by deployers themselves via config. A deployer will be able to make a plugin that adds custom workflow/tasks, and exposes that over an API, as well as tweaking existing core 'micro-APIs' to slightly better suit their needs. This means they potentially can augment things in such a way that breaks interoperability, but likely will not most of the time.

> Is this an accurate summation of Adjutant?
> 
> "Shade/SDK-as-a-Service" + deployer scripting -> Horizon panels
> 
> In other words, it overlaps more with Oaktree than anything else,
> exchanging the HTTP/2+proto bufs for a Django web front-end and
> non-predictable behaviour.

Yes and no. Deployer scripting is a part of it, an optional part, making it work well is part of the focus of the project, but mostly to provide nicer ways to augment core features and workflow.

As for Oaktree, the scope and focus is very different. Adjutant isn't here to allow deployers to write a layer to solve the problem's it solves:
> oaktree is for end-users who do not and should not know what hypervisor,
> what storage driver or what network stack the deployer has chosen.
> The two sets of people are different audiences, so oaktree is a project
> to support the end user.
Adjutant 'could' be used for this, but such 'micro-APIs' would NEVER end up in core, and we wouldn't support deployers who do it via plugins.

> But it appears to actually be both.  and honestly I do not have a
> lot of sympathy for a project that encourages random
> non-interoperable functionality being exposed to users. 
> Interoperability is important to us and the work we have today is
> already greatly limited in scope due to a few particular public
> clouds that have not and will not fully embrace the OpenStack APIs.
> We need to expand the interoperability standards not encourage more
> vendor lock-in.
> 
> I totally understand why cloud operators want something like this,
> they generally do not care about interoperability beyond whatever
> stick is used to push them toward the trademark carrot.
> 
> But as someone heavily invested in the cloud consuming client world
> I can not support a further fragmentation of our ecosystem.
> 
> https://xkcd.com/927/

You may not intend it to sound as such, but you make it seem like interoperability is all or nothing, which isn't the case. There are so many areas that regardless of our efforts will never be interoperable between clouds. There are also many the might be, and others were a level of quasi-interoperability might be able to exist.

Adjutant could potentially help quite a lot with interoperability in the areas that currently have none. While I don't want to place emphasis on it, I do want that to be clear that, yes it has the _potential_ to introduce more interoperability problems, but the benefits far outweigh the negatives. We can introduce plenty of useful and easily augmentable account management and admin 'micro-APIs' that help build better business logic automation around the things most of those clouds would do themselves. We can start building these small bridges between how users manage themselves on OpenStack and how the cloud deployer runs things.

An example of something that could help a hell of a lot:
One of the original design decisions in Adjutant was to abstract out our interactions with Keystone into an IdentityManager that could be made plugable (https://blueprints.launchpad.net/adjutant/+spec/plugable-identity-manager). The reason for this being that we could allow a single interface in Adjutant that would work the same on multiple clouds for managing users, but behind the scenes talked to the correct user backend (Keystone itself, LDAP, AD, etc). Keystone used to be able to create and manage users in LDAP, but that changed. Adjutant could act as the ideal bridge for such a problem for clouds that need it, and users benefit because the interaction for managing themselves and their project users is the same.

This is what we want to achieve. And what you should understand about Catalyst as company is that we want to encourage interoperability. We don't want vendor lock-in, we are an opensource first company and that is why we go through great lengths to do things upstream first, and make anything we do compatible with OpenStack itself or fit within the scope of the community. Even our hack of an MFA solution fits within that and work was done to make sure we can migrate to better MFA support later: https://github.com/catalyst-cloud/adjutant-mfa

I think Adjutant has the potential to help with interoperability if used and developed correctly, and to add a little regarding Chris Dent's question, being under the TC helps with that. Catalyst will continue to develop and use Adjutant regardless of it being an Official project or not, and in all likelyhood other clouds providers will eventually also start using it (two already do from memory). Being Official means the TC can actually help us avoid interoperability problems and encourage clouds to not augment and customise Adjutant in ways that break the pieces of interoperability that we care about.

Also Dean, I am very invested in our cloud consuming clients. Almost all my work uses those and I respect the work that is done there so much. Which is why one of the biggest things I want to achieve with Adjutant one day is capability discovery so any tools that use it, can correctly help bridge any differences between clouds using Adjutant, or even automatically support the extra features the cloud deployer has built into it.

In all likelyhood most of the user interactions with Adjutant will be dashboard based, but yes, the APIs do exist and users can use them. So we'll make the tools smart to handle the differences, and the service to respond with what it can do.


@GrahamHayes Your comments are spot on. Being official helps us get more people involved, and helps operators feel safer that we are doing development under the guidance of the TC and in a way that benefits the ecosystem as a whole.
 

@ThierryCarrez

> In the Adjutant case, they are definitely aligned with the way we
> do things, and there is a good product fit (part of the
> openstack-operators bucket). I'm less convinced they would benefit
> from being set up as a level playing field, and more importantly
> I'm concerned that OpenStack-the-framework will be lot less
> interoperable with that project in than with this project out.

Ideally I don't want us to position it as OpenStack-the-framework. Part of me is joking referring to it as MSaaS (Mirco Service as a Service), but the parts of the scope that would be in the core project itself are all in the Administrative and Operations business logic automation space and I don't really ever intend us to stray too far outside of that.

Things like password resets, or multi-service customer termination (clear all resources across all customer projects), managing account details, sign-ups, quota management. Things that ideally could be the same in multiple clouds, and wrappers around normally admin only actions.

As already said above, the potential for helping interoperability in this space is huge, and if we do it right we can allow augmentations that still make these 'mirco-APIs' mostly compatible, or write tools that correctly handle such differences because the tools themselves are dynamic.


@ZaneBitter
> TBH this is the most alarming part to me.
> 
> You say yourself that the feature would be better implemented in Neutron,
> and you appear to be unaware that it is also squarely in-scope for Congress.

From what I remember Congress is entirely audit based. You declare policies, and it complains if those polices aren't met and has the potential to clean up? Yes that could potentially work for a problem like that, but... it is a problem better solved before creation. If congress had pre-creation support for service actions themselves (does it?) then that would be wonderful, because the notion of letting it happen and fixing it afterwards doesn't sit well with me.

As for doing it in Adjutant, honestly, I don't want to and won't. I was just making an example of something that could potentially be done that I had considered although decided was a bad idea.
 
> The last thing I want to see in OpenStack is a catch-all project that exists
> for the purpose of being easier to get random features into than the projects
> where they actually belong. The only thing worse than that would be if there
> were multiple such projects.
> 
> I don't think I can be comfortable with this in the absence of a
> tightly-defined scope.

The scope really is mostly focused on administrative and operations automation of business logic on behalf of users. Those are the kind of features we'd keep in core, and anything built by deployers that strays far too far out of that scope will not be supported. I'm just also trying to be clear that because of the pluggable nature of Adjutant, nothing is stopping someone from doing stupid and crazy out of scope things.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-04-04 15:06:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks, Adrian, for being patient with us while we bounce these ideas around and taking the time to provide some thoughtful responses. Whatever the outcome of this particular application, I hope you'll also provide your thoughts at the forum session about evaluating official projects (line 25 (as of today) on https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-forum-TC-sessions ).

 > @ChrisDent Responses to some of your points below (tried to address
 > the most relevant ones).

Thanks. I'm aware that many of the comments I made are rather ambiguous. That's part of the point I was trying to make.

 > But is there really an "OpenStack" product? Maybe back when it was
 > just one project mostly all under the Nova codebase back in the
 > day. OpenStack is an ecosystem, isn't it? At which point having
 > lots of pieces that work together becomes a strength as to how much
 > that ecosystem thrives.

This is one of the root questions indeed. If we're striving to be consistent, based on which projects we've accepted in the recent past, then "ecosystem" is probably accurate and we should stick to that, at least until we make some kind of formal statement that we are not doing that any longer.

 > Has OpenStack ever done that [evaluted based on use and popularity]?

You're right, we haven't (at least not recently). And again, until we make some kind of statement otherwise, we shouldn't bend the (de facto) rules.

However, I do think it is something we should consider changing. And we should also consider this:

 > Maybe what we instead need is a process where we check the health
 > of projects and potentially retire them if no traction or uptake
 > has occurred or we don't block that space for potentially better
 > projects

[lots of useful stuff snipped]

 > The scope really is mostly focused on administrative and operations
 > automation of business logic on behalf of users. Those are the kind
 > of features we'd keep in core, and anything built by deployers that
 > strays far too far out of that scope will not be supported. I'm
 > just also trying to be clear that because of the pluggable nature
 > of Adjutant, nothing is stopping someone from doing stupid and
 > crazy out of scope things.

Yeah, I think we need to be careful about differentiating between what a project is intended for and what it is possible to do with it.

Underlying some of the concerns presented in this discussion is the big hope that OpenStack can legitimately be a properly interoperable cloud where code that uses the "official" APIs correctly and works as expected on OpenStack cloud A can continue to work, without modification, on OpenStack cloud B. I think it is fair to recognize that there are interactions that one makes with a particular instantiation of an OpenStack cloud that are outside the boundaries of the official APIs, but we've done a poor job of delineating that boundary.

To me, it sounds like the intent of Adjutant is to help in areas that are outside the boundary, but that it has the capability to be used within the boundaries (seeing aside for a moment that where that boundary is is not well defined).

/me is still thinking'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-04-05 13:20:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks Adrian for your patient responses to our open brainstorming around this !

I feel like there are two main concerns here:

1- Presenting Adjutant as an "API factory" around any business logic raises interoperability fears. We don't really want an official "OpenStack service" with an open-ended API or set of APIs.

2- There is concern that some of the "core plugins" could actually be implemented in existing projects, and that Adjutant is working around the pain of landing those features in the (set of) projects where they belong by creating a whole-new project to land them faster.

To address (1), I'm wondering if Adjutant should not focus on the "core plugins", to the point where they would not be considered plugins but features you can switch off. The code base could still support external features by loading extra modules on a configurable path, much like you can plug external code into Nova through module loading. But those non-interoperable extra features would be clearly external and additions, rather than be seen as a part of the "official service". The distinction is subtle and mostly around how we communicate about Adjutant itself: a self-service API for some _specific_ business logic, rather than an API factory for whatever you want to add to OpenStack. I see another benefit in convergence: you'd encourage people to reuse the core "password reset" API rather than encourage people to come up with their own variant of password reset API.

To address (2) I think we need to dive into the core functionality and have a good discussion on whether it really would fit into other projects. Maybe we can find a volunteer from the TC to look into each of the planned "core functions" and work with you into determining if this should/could really be implemented without creating a whole new project.

Combining the two, we could come up with a precise scope for Adjutant that would hopefully make us more confident that accepting it as an official OpenStack component won't bring more drawbacks than benefits.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-04-06 00:01:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@ChrisDent

 > Thanks, Adrian, for being patient with us while we bounce these
 > ideas around and taking the time to provide some thoughtful
 > responses. Whatever the outcome of this particular application, I
 > hope you'll also provide your thoughts at the forum session about
 > evaluating official projects (line 25 (as of today) on
 > https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-forum-TC-sessions ).

I always expected this process to take a while, both because you want to be careful with what you label as official, and because Adjutant itself is a very weird service. In a way my expectations of this process were that I'd have to reconsider what Adjutant was, its scope, and some of the work we've got to do before reaching v1.0.0 and I'm happy that this back and forth is helping me exactly with that. Both in prepping for this review and during it we've opened a bunch of blueprints to track future work, and written some docs to help us better grasp our own focus.

So you're welcome, and thanks also to the rest of you having to trawl through this discussion. :)

 > To me, it sounds like the intent of Adjutant is to help in areas
 > that are outside the boundary, but that it has the capability to be
 > used within the boundaries (seeing aside for a moment that where
 > that boundary is is not well defined).

In a way that's mostly it. There are areas of overlap, or areas where Adjutant was built/is used for that are firmly in Keystone land, but not in a way that is really useful to a company like us (Keystone shouldn't be sending emails, nor talking to external systems). So it is really really hard to define where Adjutant sits. It really dances on that boundary. Most of what the service is used for, or will be used for are things that cloud deployers have historically always had to do themselves in their own custom systems, but for things that interact with things in OpenStack land.

Both drawing the boundary is hard, and figuring out where Adjutant fits even if there is a boundary.


@ThierryCarrez

 > To address (1), I'm wondering if Adjutant should not focus on the
 > "core plugins", to the point where they would not be considered
 > plugins but features you can switch off. The code base could still
 > support external features by loading extra modules on a
 > configurable path, much like you can plug external code into Nova
 > through module loading. But those non-interoperable extra features
 > would be clearly external and additions, rather than be seen as a
 > part of the "official service". The distinction is subtle and
 > mostly around how we communicate about Adjutant itself: a
 > self-service API for some _specific_ business logic, rather than an
 > API factory for whatever you want to add to OpenStack. I see
 > another benefit in convergence: you'd encourage people to reuse the
 > core "password reset" API rather than encourage people to come up
 > with their own variant of password reset API.

In a way this is exactly why the plugins exist. Anything that isn't useful to _everyone_ shouldn't be in core. But... anything that is in core should still be able to be augmented. Adjutant in its current form has (and after we rework the internals will still have) a way to augment a workflow without outright overriding it but I still feel uncomfortable enforcing any API.

Password reset is a good example because it's one that deployers (especially public clouds) often handle themselves. Yes we can encourage them to use Adjutant's, but they may not entirely want to, and honestly password reset is normally gui based so interoperability isn't exactly an issue if the gui is self explanatory. Do we really need to have such strong interoperability worries about normally gui based features? Yes there is an API, but one no one uses directly. Adjutant _will_ eventually have another API for password resets that allows admins and project_admins to force a password reset, and that _may_ be used directly.

Or what if a deployer who uses an external system for users and federates their Keystone? If they want to still use the password reset in Adjutant they have two options, write their own IdentityManager for Adjutant (which will be pluggable) which the default password reset workflow and API use, or they may decide to still use Adjutant's default password reset UI and API as a template and write their own entirely custom password reset workflow that behind the scenes talks to their federated source. Potentially because the logic needed isn't entirely compatible with how we use the IdentityManager. If we enforce no modification on password reset (because we assume it is universally useful) we potentially stop a deployer from using it at all and thus also introducing an interoperability problem. The flexibility in this kind of federated example is potentially a huge benefit.

That's why rather than enforcement, our focus has been on encouragement, making the 'core' elements as either building blocks, or fully featured workflow/API that can be augmented without changing the API too much:
e.g. API endpoint path stays the same, internal workflow changes a bit, maybe now the API requires an extra field in the request json when posting to it.

The above is exactly how Catalyst Cloud's custom signup logic works. Adjutant has a default signup API and workflow. Ours is built on top of that:
https://catalystcloud.nz/signup/
posts to
https://github.com/catalyst-cloud/adjutant-odoo

Yes what the API requires is different, but beyond that it 'mostly' works the same. Plus my eventual goal is to have those kinds of differences discoverable so that any client tools can tell you exactly what the API expects.

In fact, Adjutant originally had that as the default GET for most of the tasks:
https://github.com/openstack/adjutant/blob/master/adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py#L46-L69
But as we moved away from 1:1 Task:API and started making the task/workflow stuff separate from the API layer that kind of never got used. What I have planned is to move to declarative Tasks and APIs with a system API to list the Micro APIs and what they require/do. This means that anything exposed by Adjutant as a 'microAPI' is discoverable and any official tools will handle differences, especially in the 'core' Micro APIs.

A consistent always backwards compatible official API to figure out what extra functionality the deployer has turned on or customised.
 
 > To address (2) I think we need to dive into the core functionality
 > and have a good discussion on whether it really would fit into
 > other projects. Maybe we can find a volunteer from the TC to look
 > into each of the planned "core functions" and work with you into
 > determining if this should/could really be implemented without
 > creating a whole new project.

I should put together a bit of a draft as to what the feature roadmap is. Mostly right now we have a ton of internal refactors to do as we clean things up and fix bad assumptions in our early design decisions.

A rough list of what Adjutant's core micro APIs do right now:
- password reset (submit username/email, email token, submit token and set password)
- signup (submit signup details, validate, approve, create project/user/default resources, email token, submit token and set password)
- manage users on project
-- list users on project,
-- invite users to project (email out an invite and token to submit)
-- manage roles of users on project
- update user email (rename username if username is email)
- manage own project qoutas (within set limits, and as grouped sizes)

And then we have an example of a use case here:
https://github.com/catalyst-cloud/adjutant-mfa

With some of the MFA example likely being moved into core when I finish the rest of the MFA work in Keystone, as setup and management of user MFA is harder to handle in Keystone itself, but that depends on how we decide to implement the self-management side of it in Keystone (if at all).

Then future features that are in progress:
- admin or project_admin can force a password reset (admin any user, project_admin users on own project)
- account termination (clear all or some resources for project, and potentially disable project)
- management/creation of sub projects
- user management and audit across whole project tree

And custom Catalyst Cloud plugins we're working on that can potentially be made more generic:
- manage account and billing details (change/select credit card via Stripe, who gets the invoice)


The big thing here that I know sticks out as a worry is that projects/users are the domain of Keystone. The issue though is that we need to do extra actions when a user or project is created (talk to external systems), as well as enforce username conventions (email), and project/sub-project name conventions (slugs, and <parent1>/<sub-project1>/<sub-project1.1>). Doing this in Keystone doesn't entirely make sense, it shouldn't need a callback to external systems on every project create, and even if it could it would need to be heavily conditional. Adjutant thus acts as the layer to handle that for us, avoid limitations in Keystone's policy and scope (that can/will be fixed later) and also handle external systems.

Or for user role management, a simple thing in Adjutant is we do a mapping of role>roles_managed_by_role such that a project_admin can edit certain roles, while a project_mod can only edit different roles. Something like this _could_ exist in Keystone, but it doesn't and likely won't for a while. Adjutant then still serves as a safer layer to handle that logic for us while Keystone doesn't have to carry more complexity.

I understand this doesn't entirely make this any easier, nor does this help make Adjutant stand out as a service that isn't so heavily coupled with the likes of Keystone, but that's the thing, it is, and it has to be, because often stuff like that doesn't fit in a project like Keystone so a layer over the top is needed. I'm just trying to be as transparent about the thought processes and the _why_ behind this service.

 > Combining the two, we could come up with a precise scope for
 > Adjutant that would hopefully make us more confident that accepting
 > it as an official OpenStack component won't bring more drawbacks
 > than benefits.

That's pretty much my ideal situation. Let's figure out a middle ground between what we need it to do, and what OpenStack needs it to be.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-04-17 02:34:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hey, just pinging for an update. I assume because the TC election is on right now this will likely end up postponed.

Also, I'm curious about how a few things I've got planned this year fit into the OpenStack ecosystem.

One of my plans for this year is to move Adjutant to be python3 only. One of the libraries I want to use (LGPL) is py3 only and Adjutant has been py3 compatible for a while. With the impending death of py27 (https://pythonclock.org) I kind of am inclined to do so. By the time Adjutant reaches v1.0.0 py27 will be dead anyway. Given the state of py27, does OpenStack support official projects that are explicitly py3? And can py3 only libraries actually be included in global-requirements?"}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-04-17 12:31:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@Adrian - I just put I6859a76846779ef687422dbbb86483c4a41b55a0 up - that should allow projects to drop the py27 requirement.

We have a few py3 only libraries, they are usually py3 versions of other requirements (e.g. dnspython and dnspython3 were different libs for a very long time), but I can't see any issues with expanding that.

For the further discussions - http://forumtopics.openstack.org/cfp/details/122 has been proposed for the forum, as it may need face to face discussions to move this forward."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-04-20 02:38:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> @Adrian - I just put I6859a76846779ef687422dbbb86483c4a41b55a0 up -

 > expanding that.
 > 
 > For the further discussions - http://forumtopics.openstack.org/cfp/details/122
