@Graham I've added a comment on the forum topic. While I sadly won't be at the summit, I'm more than happy to dial in on a voice or video call. :)

Also, thanks for the py3 related patch. It looks mostly like it may happen, which I'm happy for because if Adjutant does get brought in as an official project, the fact that it will likely be py3 only very soon may not be a problem!"}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-04-24 08:03:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Thanks Adrian for your patient responses to our open brainstorming
 > around this !
 > 
 > I feel like there are two main concerns here:
 > 
 > 1- Presenting Adjutant as an "API factory" around any business
 > logic raises interoperability fears. We don't really want an
 > official "OpenStack service" with an open-ended API or set of APIs.
 > 
 > 2- There is concern that some of the "core plugins" could actually
 > be implemented in existing projects, and that Adjutant is working
 > around the pain of landing those features in the (set of) projects
 > where they belong by creating a whole-new project to land them
 > faster.
 > 
 > To address (1), I'm wondering if Adjutant should not focus on the
 > "core plugins", to the point where they would not be considered
 > plugins but features you can switch off. The code base could still
 > support external features by loading extra modules on a
 > configurable path, much like you can plug external code into Nova
 > through module loading. But those non-interoperable extra features
 > would be clearly external and additions, rather than be seen as a
 > part of the "official service". The distinction is subtle and
 > mostly around how we communicate about Adjutant itself: a
 > self-service API for some _specific_ business logic, rather than an
 > API factory for whatever you want to add to OpenStack. I see
 > another benefit in convergence: you'd encourage people to reuse the
 > core "password reset" API rather than encourage people to come up
 > with their own variant of password reset API.
 > 
 > To address (2) I think we need to dive into the core functionality
 > and have a good discussion on whether it really would fit into
 > other projects. Maybe we can find a volunteer from the TC to look
 > into each of the planned "core functions" and work with you into
 > determining if this should/could really be implemented without
 > creating a whole new project.
 > 
 > Combining the two, we could come up with a precise scope for
 > Adjutant that would hopefully make us more confident that accepting
 > it as an official OpenStack component won't bring more drawbacks
 > than benefits.

Point #2 was my main concern, as a lot of Adjudant's focus is on identity things. But after looking through the existing code a bit (I didn't deep dive into it, and it would be nice to get a real design braindump on it) it looks and feels to me more like workflow wrappers around primitives exposed in keystone, rather than workarounds for keystone's flaws, and I think that is a perfectly fine thing to have outside of keystone, just the same as shade implements a workflow wrapper around e.g. assigning an IP address to a server.

I don't have strong feelings on point #1, and I trust the people who do have strong feelings about it. But it also seems to me like the APIs this enables are often going to be specific to the business needs of the cloud provider and so inherently non-interoperable components, so its open-endedness doesn't concern me that much.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-05-07 20:22:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I did a bit of deep-dive and it seems like a lot of what Adjutant does are stop-gaps for things that can actually be done with OpenStack services, but that's what I understand from the code, so please let me know:

  adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:CreateProject
  adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:InviteUser

The above two 'tasks' from what I understand are things that should be possible if you are using the correct policy configuration inside Keystone.  However, I think that this goes back to the Keystone admin-ness problem - https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/968696 - However, I don't know if we should maintain a project for workarounds for things that should be properly implemented.

  adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:ResetPassword

This one is interesting because it actually provides an *unauthenticated* request, as most of the other requests require authentication and there is not really a concept of unauthenticated requests in most OpenStack APIs.  I see value in something like this.

  adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:EditUser
  adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:UpdateEmail

Both of these are things that can also policy controlled.  Is there any other tasks that are possible?

All in all, I think that Mistral is reasonable to help create existing workflows to be used.  However, I think the value that Adjutant can add is for tasks that are unauthenticated due to the fact that there is not really an OpenStack service that does this.

I would imagine that you could possibly maintain the existing infrastructure of the dashboard but connect that to Mistral workflows instead, which would mean a lot less code to maintain for you and making the scope easier to define for you.

Thank you for being so patient, as well. :)"}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-05-08 01:59:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@MohammedNaser Thanks for the review!

Alright, let me try and answer some of this and why it doesn't entirely fit in Keystone. Apologies for how long this might get!

 > adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:CreateProject
 > adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:InviteUser
 > 
 > The above two 'tasks' from what I understand are things that should
 > be possible if you are using the correct policy configuration
 > inside Keystone.  However, I think that this goes back to the
 > Keystone admin-ness problem - https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/968696
 > - However, I don't know if we should maintain a project for
 > workarounds for things that should be properly implemented.

First `adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:CreateProject` is actually one we will end up removing at some stage, and will be moved entirely to: `adjutant/api/v1/openstack.SignUp`. This API and underlying workflow is specific to signup and is actually an unauthenticated API. The idea being it is used for prospective signups to POST their details and be entered into the system. Adjutant then runs validation actions to confirm it is a valid signup (project name doesn't clash, etc). This then notifies an admin who can approve the signup, at which point Adjutant creates the project, a user (with a long random password), role assignments, and an optional default neutron network. The user is then emailed what is effectively a password reset token so they can setup their password.

This API/workflow is the main reason Adjutant actually exists and the first use case we looked at. Keystone cannot nor should it handle new user registration in this fashion. Nor did we think an unauthed API was a good idea in keystone.

We needed a place to store signups before they were confirmed (Keystone has no concept of this nor should it), and we didn't want to ask for a password until we approved the signup, hence the need for a password reset like token. And we wanted to eventually be able to have the signup process automatically approve itself once we added in more complex validation logic.

Keystone does not, nor should it send out emails (but that can be debated, I think it shouldn't), password reset and registration systems need to send out emails.

In addition, as part of our Catalyst Cloud specific signup process we need our signup validation and creation to talk to our external ERP system. Keystone should not do that, yes Keystone once had extensions, but it was a bad idea and was dropped. Adjutant has a very flexible plugin mechanism that while entirely done yet, allows us to augment the default inbuilt signup actions with our own that talk to external system. We do that here with this plugin:
https://github.com/catalyst-cloud/adjutant-odoo

None of this could be solved with Policy alone, and much of the parts Adjutant solves in this particular task are ones that don't fit in the project scope of Keystone, but do need to use the primitives exposed in Keystone.


`adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:InviteUser` could partly be solved by policy, but again it includes email as part of the process. An email is sent out to confirm the invite and in the case the user is entirely new, that includes a password set token since we don't want to create the user with a password until they confirm it (email address may be wrong).

In addition, Keystone has no concept of role mappings. Basically based on the roles you have, what roles can you edit. This actually may have a place in Keystone, but before that we still need to properly fix the 'adminness' issue. While the way Adjutant handles this does need to be changed, effectively it amounts to a mapping like this:
https://github.com/openstack/adjutant/blob/master/conf/conf.yaml#L319-L334

When you invite a user, or edit their roles with `adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:EditUser` we make sure you are only doing that with the roles are allowed to manage. Keystone probably can eventually include this, and it would be VERY useful. Provided that is the case then EditUser could be done entirely through Keystone with policy.

You can potentially achieve the same thing as role mappings in policy with conditions, but I wouldn't do that as it would make your policy an even more complicated giant mess.

 > adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:ResetPassword
 > 
 > This one is interesting because it actually provides an
 > *unauthenticated* request, as most of the other requests require
 > authentication and there is not really a concept of unauthenticated
 > requests in most OpenStack APIs.  I see value in something like
 > this.
 > 

As already mentioned above, this isn't just an unauthenticated endpoint. A password reset process in almost all services consists of supplying your email (and username potentially), at which point the system checks if a user matching those details exists, and sends them an email containing a long token which lets them update their password once. This requires email, as that is often the only vaguely safe way to confirm they are who they say they are. Keystone has no easy method to achieve something similar without also sending emails, and also including a view in Horizon where said tokens can be consumed.

Adjutant does exactly that. It provides via Adjutant-ui an unauthenticated view in Horizon to submit your password-reset. This sends a request to Adjutant itself to process the reset, and if a valid user is found, an email is sent with a link to another unauthenticated panel in Horizon where you can consume said token.

The way Adjutant-UI actually does this is rather odd as we have to work around Horizon constructs, but it works surprisingly well.

I don't see Keystone introducing anything like this as a password reset workflow.

 > adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:EditUser
 > adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:UpdateEmail
 > 
 > Both of these are things that can also policy controlled.  Is there
 > any other tasks that are possible?

As already mentioned with `adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:EditUser`, yes it potentially could if there was a concept for role management mappings.

`adjutant/api/v1/tasks.py:UpdateEmail` no because it actually does more than just update your email or rename your user. If Adjutant is configured to assume USERNAME_IS_EMAIL then updating your email is updating your username. Updating a username itself could be unsafe because of potential clashes being used to collect a list of usernames, which we avoid by enforcing emails as usernames, and if that wasn't the case I'd be reluctant to allow a username change to users. If USERNAME_IS_EMAIL=False, then updating an email is just updating an 'extra' value on the user in Keystone.

In either case though, updating an email requires Adjutant to email the new email address to confirm it exists. That email includes a token which must be confirmed before the email (or username) will be updated. This way the user doesn't accidentally change their email or username to an email that doesn't exist or they don't control. The old username/email also gets sent an email telling them this action was done.
 
 > All in all, I think that Mistral is reasonable to help create
 > existing workflows to be used.  However, I think the value that
 > Adjutant can add is for tasks that are unauthenticated due to the
 > fact that there is not really an OpenStack service that does this.

Mistral doesn't really fit in business workflow like this. It can't expose that workflow directly as APIs, you can't have it send out notifications easily to outside systems about those, or have it talk to outside systems for some of it's actions. Yes it can be changed to do so with custom workflow code, but it isn't really built for this kind of workflow, nor does it have the same kind of approval step built in. You could have tasks send out notifications and then pause themselves and require an unpause action by and admin for the workflow to continue, but that's a workaround rather than a truly appropriate use case.

There is nothing stopping us from making an action in Adjutant that can be used in its workflows that calls workflows in Mistral, but the audit history and business logic workflow makes more sent in Adjutant itself. Mistral is better for resource based workflow rather than business logic based workflow, and there are certain actions in Adjutant that could be made simpler by moving their logic to Mistral, but because I don't want to overburden deployer complexity, Adjutant's own actions are just python code so they can handle it just fine. An optional soft dependency with Mistral is an option, but I don't know if any of the core action in Adjutant should ever do that, but nothing stops deployers writing their own custom actions and tasks which do call Mistral.

Adjutant is the top level logic layer, and while it is lacking a bit of flexibility in the workflow right now, that will change in time.
 
 > 
 > I would imagine that you could possibly maintain the existing
 > infrastructure of the dashboard but connect that to Mistral
 > workflows instead, which would mean a lot less code to maintain for
 > you and making the scope easier to define for you.

I did consider this a long time ago, but the issue is that we needed these workflows expose as an API, not a generic API to call any workflow. Adjutant both acts as a wrapper around the workflow and exposes an API that represents it, but also as way to wrap logic around how a given user with given permissions might trigger said workflow.
 
 > Thank you for being so patient, as well. :)

Not a problem! Adjutant is not an easy service to get your head around, even for me, and I wrote most of it.

There is one additional note I'd like to add that makes Adjutant quite useful for something Keystone can't solve. Adjutant was always designed to have the user store backend be pluggable. We never finished that since we're the only company developing it right now and our user store is keystone, but that part of the code is purposefully abstract so we can easily make the IdentityManager plugabble. This means if your backend is LDAP, or AD, or something else, Adjutant can still manage your users. Keystone has deprecated the ability for it to manage users in LDAP (create, update, etc), so Adjutant acting as the go between that does actions in both Keystone for authz config, and in <insert_backend> for authn config is really powerful. This is probably the closest thing to a 'generic' OpenStack user management and password reset system OpenStack could have."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-05-08 02:02:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Sorry about the formatting for that response...

Weird issues like that makes me wish markdown or RST formatting existed in gerrit reviews.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-05-08 05:48:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I agree with all of Adrian's counterpoints in the last comment. I'll also mention a couple of things about keystone that make it unsuitable for the kind of things Adjutant does:

1. Email is not a first-class property of a keystone user. It's implemented as a key in a JSON blob in the 'extra' column. There's no policy that would allow a user to edit just their email without giving them full control of user updates because we don't really want users to be adding arbitrary data to that JSON blob.
2. The attributes of a keystone user are deliberately pretty minimal because we want to drive operators toward using external identity storage systems like LDAP/AD or SSO systems, and because we expect and want people to create tooling like Adjutant to manage business-specific logic that keystone has no business being involved with.

Probably some of the workflows that Adjutant implements would have been easier to solve if the admin-ness problem was a little closer to being fully fixed, but I think most of the keystone team would agree that most of this doesn't really belong in keystone."}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-05-08 12:51:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Adrian,

Thank you for the replies, I really appreciate it.  I wanted to follow up with the question of.. why don't you leave the 'workflow' engine inside Mistral and keep Adjutant to do the management only?

I am not opposed to Adjutant, it does what it does well, but it seems to have taken a bit too much out of it's scope.  All what you're doing can still exist (living outside auth, APIs, etc) while relying on Mistral as an execution engine to run the workflows

Please correct me if my analogy is incorrect, but it feels like if we were to compare Adjutant to Octavia, it would be as if Octavia built it's own VM provisioning platform without leveraging Nova?

In any case, I think we have to balance between a very fine line of being a home for innovation and helping projects within the OpenStack ecosystem grow, but while at the same time not confusing new users who might be looking at a 'workflow as a service' project.

Maybe it would be best if you could summarize or answer this question: How would you explain to someone new to OpenStack about why they should use Adjutant vs Mistral and vice versa.  Perhaps, clear documentation explaining the scope of each one might be the best solution?"}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2018-05-08 14:12:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Please correct me if my analogy is incorrect, but it feels like if we were to compare Adjutant to Octavia, it would be as if Octavia built it's own VM provisioning platform without leveraging Nova?

I would probably compare that to Octavia not using Heat to control the lifecycle of amphora, rather than Nova.
Co-incidentally Octavia does not use Heat, (and last time I looked, neither did Trove).

Using Mistral for some components of a task, (say a task to send an email / create a project / create a network)
which gets run, the result / task id stored in Adjutant, which waits for the next step to happen (via API - say an Admin approving something, or a user clicking a link in an email) will mean that Adjutant will still have to maintain its own internal task runner, but some of the steps in a Adjutant task will be Mistral workflows.

Personally, I don't see a massive benefit from this - a lot of openstack projects have some sort of task mechanism built in that don't use Mistral."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-05-10 05:35:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@ColleenMurphy

"we expect and want people to create tooling like Adjutant to manage business-specific logic that keystone has no business being involved with"
^ that is exactly why we're trying to get Adjutant included as an official project. So that ideally we can make it flexible enough to work for the majority of deployers who are trying to solve this, rather than having to do it themselves. Less duplicate effort, more sharing of resources and knowledge. I'm not saying Adjutant is the best solution, but in the absence of any solution it's better than nothing. A collaborative project focused on fitting into OpenStack that helps bridge the gap between business specific requirements across deployments is something we need. We can always make Adjutant better as more use cases and experience in this space is added to the fold.

Side topic: Your point number 2 is actually an interesting one for us (Catalyst Cloud) because we use Keystone as our user store. We originally did plan on switching to LDAP but found that we didn't gain enough outright benefit from it for the complexity it added. Sure we could define user schema with extra fields, but we'd still need to build something for password reset, user creation and management, etc. LDAP is after all just a database with yet another interface. In the end Keystone is our source of truth for authn and authz, and we can do everything with its API, and that is probably not going to change at this stage. That said, the minimal attributes work for us since the user construct is independent of our concept of a 'customer'. A user is just a username (their email), their password, and their MFA creds and rules. The lack of an email field doesn't hurt us because username==email, but even in the case where email needs to be in the extra blob, that's not so bad with something like Adjutant. We do use the json blob, but not for hugely important data. Customer data we store in our ERP system, with a mapping from customer to the projects they own. With Adjutant helping us maintain those mappings. Users are actually independent of that because one user may have access to the projects of more than one customer. This separation of business/customer info and users actually makes Keystone as our identity source entirely sufficient, and I bet there are lots of other deployers who are in a similar situation.

So one of the other benefits for Adjutant is that it builds around Keystone enough of that business logic that some organizations might already have in their existing user store system, hence why federating Keystone is so useful. They can reuse their existing user management tools. But for smaller deployments that just want a thing that works out of the box, Adjutant could potentially add around Keystone enough of those elements that mean they don't also now need to stand up and maintain an LDAP or AD and the pieces around that. If they need extra information on the user model then they have no choice but use LDAP/AD etc, and Adjutant can still help them avoid needing to build some extra stuff around that, but Keystone in many ways is now pretty sufficient, and Adjutant could compliment it fairly well without requiring Keystone to expand its scope.

@MohammedNaser

Graham is pretty much spot on. Mistral can't handle the top level logic the way Adjutant does, even if we used Mistral, we can't rely on Mistral for storing the history and management of that top level logic so we'd still have small workflow layer anyway. Mistral is also Workflow as a service, Adjutant doesn't let you define workflow outside of the code.

From my understanding of the service, Mistral has actions it can run as part of workflow, and it has an API which lets you define a workflow built around those actions. The workflows it can do are therefore dynamically added/managed via the API.

Adjutant's workflows are all in code and config, and baring some very drastic changes will remain as such. You define actions, you define a task (a workflow) that uses those actions, and then you make an API (or multiple APIs) that behind the scenes use said task. Sometimes an API or a series of APIs are actually multiple tasks all built around a larger business process.'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-05-10 09:13:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Correct. To expand slightly; Mistral workflows are all written in a YAML based DSL. Actions are written in Python (and essentially just a function) and there is a standard set and you can add your own custom actions. The Workflows essentially run a set of Python actions (albeit potentially in an advanced way with parallelisation and distribution etc.). Actions are added at install time and Workflows via the API.

I think everything you would expose via Adjutant will be added at install time.

(Not sure "install time" is the right way to describe it, but I guess you know what I mean - When you setup and upgrade not something you generally change on the fly. I guess really it is a cloud administrator task and not a cloud user).

My biggest concern is terminology and user confusion. I know Mistral well and think I understand Adjutant well enough to see the different project goals. However, based on the discussion I am reading here it seems clear that people are confusing the two. Also, if you look at the Mistral and Adjutant documentation they both use similar terminology - Workflows, Actions, Tasks. I wonder if that is just asking for trouble over time. Mistral uses "openstack workflow ...", "openstack action ..." and "openstack task ..." CLI commands (and a few others). Adjutant users after reading the docs could assume they are relevant. I'm not sure how we can solve this and to be fair they are very generic words but it does concern me.'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-05-10 09:43:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> My biggest concern is terminology and user confusion. I know

 > if that is just asking for trouble over time. Mistral uses
 > "openstack workflow ...", "openstack action ..." and "openstack
 > task ..." CLI commands (and a few others). Adjutant users after
 > reading the docs could assume they are relevant. I'm not sure how
 > we can solve this and to be fair they are very generic words but it
 > does concern me.

(I knew I would think of something else as soon as I clicked "Post".)

I actually wonder if this discussion went down this path due to a terminology issue. Adjutants use of workflows is essentially a implementation detail. Users shouldn't need to care about that. If the conversation had started something like "Adjutant is a OpenStack service for creating API endpoints in your cloud to do X, Y Z" and there was no mention of Workflows then I doubt the comparison with Mistral would have happened.

I would guess that many other OpenStack services have something internally that either is a workflow or could be called one. What is a Workflow anyway? I think it means different things to different people and I have this problem when I talk about Mistral. I like to tell people "It is a workflow service!" but then they ask what that means and I start to hand wave a bit.

Having said that, to be clear, I would be happy to help investigate and explore the idea of any service that wants to use Mistral for its internal workflows. In this case it sounds like the Adjutant developers already looked into this and we should trust their conclusion.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-10 22:03:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Mohammed's insight that the APIs Adjutant is providing all involve alternate means of authentication seems like a very useful one. As a starting point, what would you add or change in the following mission statement?

"To provide a UI and API for business process automation around the aspects of user management that cannot use Keystone authentication."

I would happily vote for something like that.

I'm satisfied that the use or otherwise of Mistral is a red herring (although I don't agree with all of your assertions about it). It's ultimately up to the developers to decide.

I would really, really like to ban any more projects from sending email (or webhooks[1]) instead of using the Mistral action or a Zaqar notification - which is already one too many ways of doing it. But I don't believe in using the new project process as a mechanism to enforce that, so consider this just friendly advice.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-May/130292.html'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-05-11 02:02:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@DougalMatthews

 > I think everything you would expose via Adjutant will be added at install time.

Mostly yes, a deployer can augment elements further with config, but the main part of the functionality as deployed is decided when you build your package/container, etc.

 > I actually wonder if this discussion went down this path due to a
 > terminology issue. Adjutants use of workflows is essentially a
 > implementation detail. Users shouldn't need to care about that. If
 > the conversation had started something like "Adjutant is a
 > OpenStack service for creating API endpoints in your cloud to do X,
 > Y Z" and there was no mention of Workflows then I doubt the
 > comparison with Mistral would have happened.
 > 
 > I would guess that many other OpenStack services have something
 > internally that either is a workflow or could be called one. What
 > is a Workflow anyway? I think it means different things to
 > different people and I have this problem when I talk about Mistral.
 > I like to tell people "It is a workflow service!" but then they ask
 > what that means and I start to hand wave a bit.
 > 
 > Having said that, to be clear, I would be happy to help investigate
 > and explore the idea of any service that wants to use Mistral for
 > its internal workflows. In this case it sounds like the Adjutant
 > developers already looked into this and we should trust their
 > conclusion.

I think you're right, and that is mostly my fault for not being clear that the workflow components of Adjutant are entirely in code or controlled by the deployer. The deliverable (as it were) to the users is just APIs for certain admin processes. The workflow part is important for deployers to understand, so they can customize it, but the service itself does not offer APIs to edit that workflow. I'm not sure if we can or should drop using those terms, but maybe we need to work on making the docs much clearer that any mention of workflows is developer focused rather than consumer focused. To be fair, the docs as they are right now are entirely dev and deployer focused, but that isn't obvious I guess.

As for Adjutant using Mistral, I fully plan to make a generic action type that can be augmented by deployers that just runs a Mistral workflow. I don't want us to do all our actions in Mistral, but I do think if Mistral is available people should have the option of running actions in it very easily.


@ZaneBitter

 > Mohammed's insight that the APIs Adjutant is providing all involve
 > alternate means of authentication seems like a very useful one. As
 > a starting point, what would you add or change in the following
 > mission statement?
 > 
 > "To provide a UI and API for business process automation around the
 > aspects of user management that cannot use Keystone
 > authentication."
 > 
 > I would happily vote for something like that.

That isn't right though. Adjutant has nothing to do with Keystone authentication in a direct sense. Adjutant uses Keystonemiddleware for auth just like every other API, but some of the APIs are specifically unauthenticated by design. That fact has no place in our mission statement, it's just an implementation detail that is not even that different from any other API (other than we don't support oslo policy yet).

Based the discussions in this review I'm leaning towards the following mission statement:
"To provide an extensible API for exposing to users an organization's automated business processes across OpenStack and external systems that can be adapted to the unique requirements of an organization's processes."
It's not far off what I have there right now, it removes the word 'task' from it, and makes it clearer (hopefully) that the mission is from a deployer/admin perspective rather than the users.

I'm shying away from mentioning 'user management' or anything like that because that isn't true. If anything it might be 'customer management' because Adjutant touches users, projects, role assignments (maybe groups eventually too), builds basic resources (an optional default network for each new customer), quotas, and will soon handle resource termination as part of account closure. I don't want to include the word customer either because that makes it sound like it isn't useful for private clouds, which isn't true.

It is a service to automate most of the tasks a user might want to trigger themselves that normally a systems admin may otherwise have to do manually across multiple systems/projects or via admin APIs that shouldn't or can't easily be made non-admin friendly. Or tasks that a systems admin may need to do in the process of managing a customer across multiple systems, that also should ideally have an audit trail.

I don't know what to call that beyond what the mission statement says, because 'user management' does not cut it.

 > I'm satisfied that the use or otherwise of Mistral is a red herring
 > (although I don't agree with all of your assertions about it). It's
 > ultimately up to the developers to decide.
 > 
 > I would really, really like to ban any more projects from sending
 > email (or webhooks[1]) instead of using the Mistral action or a
 > Zaqar notification - which is already one too many ways of doing
 > it. But I don't believe in using the new project process as a
 > mechanism to enforce that, so consider this just friendly advice.
 > 
 > [1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-May/130292.html

Adjutant has to send emails, you can't make a signup system that doesn't, or a password reset system that doesn't, and they are sent out with generated dynamic templates. Relying on Mistral for that is a near pointless level of complexity. Yes we could, but why would we when Django already has plenty of good ways to handle email sending and templating? To achieve what we already have via Mistral would be a lot of work. Adding Mistral as a hard requirement (or even a soft one) adds nothing useful at all.

Adjutant does have it's own inbuilt and VERY basic notification model that is meant to be pluggable so Zaqar is planned there, but this would be a soft requirement. Although in reality this whole part of the code needs to be rethought.

As least for webhooks, Adjutant doesn't do webhooks, not really. Adjutant's Tokens are an ID that lets you post data to an unauthenticated endpoint to finish the final step of a workflow. These are user triggered manually, and that's potentially the closest thing to a webhook we might have.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-05-11 08:19:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Even if Adjutant does more than just unauthenticated API endpoints, I think it sets it apart from other components so it might be worth calling in the scope statement ("...including unauthenticated...").

Also I like the suggestion to avoid terminology overlap and limit usage of "Actions", "Workflows", "Tasks" as much as possible to Mistral. I feel like "Business logic" captures the idea that those are deployer-level logic rather than enduser-level logic.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-05-11 14:10:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I feel like we're still a bit in the weeds talking about implementation details.

If we ignore how it works, my understanding is that Adjutant is a service for deployers to place their APIs for integrating with their backend services for doing "orchestration" things triggered by user action but that may involve extra business logic, manual approval steps, or other kinds of validation that are outside of the scope of individual existing OpenStack services. As someone who has dealt with public and private cloud deployments, I know that is a very important space for us to be addressing, and I'm glad to see someone starting to do it.

My issue with the current stated plans are that rather than masking deployment-dependent integration and configuration using a standard set of well-known APIs, the Adjutant team's goal is explicitly to allow deployers to add whatever APIs they want. And *that* is not like anything else we're currently doing elsewhere in OpenStack. In fact, it's the opposite direction we've gone with the other projects that used to support API extensions.

So, while Adjutant undoubtedly addresses the needs of some OpenStack users, it unclear to me that it does so in a way that is compatible with the goals and mission of the overall community, which wants to have stable, standard, and interoperable APIs across multiple deployments. And from a governance perspective, this disconnect in terms of goals, rather than any implementation details related to the code, still makes me hesitate to support adding Adjutant as an official project.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-05-15 02:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Even if Adjutant does more than just unauthenticated API endpoints,
> I think it sets it apart from other components so it might be worth
> calling in the scope statement ("...including unauthenticated...").

That's just a feature of keystonemiddleware that any other service can do. Even in our homebrew billing service we were going to do something similar to have 'prices' as a public endpoint which our website and others could query.
https://github.com/openstack/keystonemiddleware/blob/master/keystonemiddleware/auth_token/_opts.py#L70-L74

There is nothing stopping another service from doing the same. Use the middleware to handle auth, but then decide what to do with it based on the headers in code, and have some endpoints public. Adjutant isn't doing anything special here, it's just an unimportant implementation detail.

> I feel like we're still a bit in the weeds talking about
> implementation details.
> 
> If we ignore how it works, my understanding is that Adjutant is a
> service for deployers to place their APIs for integrating with
> their backend services for doing "orchestration" things triggered
> by user action but that may involve extra business logic, manual
> approval steps, or other kinds of validation that are outside of
> the scope of individual existing OpenStack services. As someone who
> has dealt with public and private cloud deployments, I know that is
> a very important space for us to be addressing, and I'm glad to see
> someone starting to do it.
> 
> My issue with the current stated plans are that rather than masking
> deployment-dependent integration and configuration using a standard
> set of well-known APIs, the Adjutant team's goal is explicitly to
> allow deployers to add whatever APIs they want. And *that* is not
> like anything else we're currently doing elsewhere in OpenStack. In
> fact, it's the opposite direction we've gone with the other
> projects that used to support API extensions.
> 
> So, while Adjutant undoubtedly addresses the needs of some
> OpenStack users, it unclear to me that it does so in a way that is
> compatible with the goals and mission of the overall community,
> which wants to have stable, standard, and interoperable APIs across
> multiple deployments. And from a governance perspective, this
> disconnect in terms of goals, rather than any implementation
> details related to the code, still makes me hesitate to support
> adding Adjutant as an official project.

I fully understand the issue you're having, but I think the issue is that you're also considering this from the wrong perspective.

You want a predefined API standard that all the clouds will implement and follow. We could make a service that defines APIs for all of this which follow a predefined standard, e.g.: "This is how you always do signup APIs in OpenStack". We can do that for everything in this area. The issue, no one will use it. Deployers need flexibility within this space, they may even have APIs already that do some of this, and they don't want to change them. We can't enforce this space in the same way we do with our other services because this isn't just touching OpenStack, this is touching systems outside of OpenStack, and many clouds have already built solutions to this.

Adjutant serves as the middle ground. A service with core APIs that can eventually become the standard, but in such a way that the 'standard' can still be subtly augmented for cloud specific logic. Deployers can pick which of the core Adjutant APIs they turn on or off if they already have APIs they'd prefer to use which Adjutant would otherwise cover. No deployer will touch Adjutant if they are forced to always use all the APIs if they already have an service/API for that same logic. We can encourage them to switch that business logic to instead go through Adjutant later, but that flexibility needs to be there.

Adjutant in time could become the default for a lot of business logic, with standard APIs, and we do ideally want to build the core APIs in Adjutant to go in that direction. But right now there is nothing in this space at all, so what we have is segmentation and no interoperability already. Going from that chaos to suddenly enforced interoperability will not work, we need a middle ground that offers standard API implementations deployers can switch to slowly, and augment as needed.

Maybe once Adjutant matures and more clouds adopt it we can build a v2 or v3 of the API that has far less flexibility, that has predefined APIs for the majority of this space with flexibility just in the backend. But right now, that's probably a death sentence for anything in this space and why no such thing exists and no major effort has occurred trying to bridge this problem.

I fully expect that as we add more things to Adjutant there will be APIs that most clouds will all end up using and not augmenting at all, and in time those will quite likely become as close to 'standard' as possible. But in this space we can't enforce anything yet.

This is a giant mess of an area, and I've already said that I don't think Adjutant is a good solution, but I don't think a truly good solution is realistically possible. Least awful solution is about the best we can hope for.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-05-15 08:59:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> So, while Adjutant undoubtedly addresses the needs of some
 > OpenStack users, it unclear to me that it does so in a way that is
 > compatible with the goals and mission of the overall community,
 > which wants to have stable, standard, and interoperable APIs across
 > multiple deployments. And from a governance perspective, this
 > disconnect in terms of goals, rather than any implementation
 > details related to the code, still makes me hesitate to support
 > adding Adjutant as an official project.

From a map perspective, Adjutant would be added in the openstack-operations bucket (under "Business logic tools") as an operators-targeted add-on to OpenStack deployments, to make their lives easier. 

So it's not really part of the "main" OpenStack product (the openstack main bucket on the map) and core set of APIs, which is why I'm ready to be more permissive with the "API factory" concern... As long as we can scope it so that it fits squarely in that business logic box.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-05-25 00:23:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Thank you everyone who was at the forum session, and sorry for the weirdness of the connection and having to speak to a person in a box!

I'll try and put together a more concise scope for Adjutant based on what is does right now, and the work we have planned for the foreseeable future. Most of that is all within the customer management scope so I think we can find something that everyone is mostly comfortable with."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-29 20:44:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Summarising the outcome of the PTG discussion for those who were not able to be present:

Committing to an open-ended mission is hard, in part because it appears to invite API incompatibility between clouds, but the mission is not written in stone. There could well be a more limited scope that still covers everything Adjutant is doing now and would be acceptable to most people. If an opportunity comes up in the future that is outside the scope as written, the TC could agree adjust the mission statement (or not) accordingly at that time. Adrian will work on a new, narrower mission statement. Graham and I are available to help from the TC side.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-05-29 20:46:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-06-28 12:10:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-28 16:22:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Linking to some more discussion from today:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-06-28.log.html#t2018-06-28T15:25:56

One question I had: what indications are there that other clouds have adopted Adjutant or are likely to in future? Looking through the logs there's no real outside commits since it was open sourced, and there are no development discussions on openstack-dev. So far I found:

* http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-operators/2017-June/013640.html
* https://bugs.launchpad.net/adjutant/+bug/1720756
* https://review.openstack.org/487823"}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-06-29 00:06:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Linking to some more discussion from today:
 > 
 > http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/%23openstack-tc.2018-06-28.log.html#t2018-06-28T15:25:56


So first point from the discussion: API is indeed meant to be user facing, but mostly will have GUI for it, and most of the interaction will be with the GUI. Certain APIs that are present in core Adjutant (invite user, edit roles, etc) make sense for a user to interact with directly as an API, but most, likely won't be. E.g. for Catalyst I'm right now building a custom Adjutant API for managing credit cards in our system/stripe, while yes the API is user accessible and requires Keystone auth, I doubt anyone will ever use it outside of Horizon (for one since it requires passing in a valid stripe card token that the gui would normally generate). While another custom API for managing your contacts in our system (who gets your invoice, who we contact during incidents, etc), 'might' be used by tech savvy companies to keep their details in sync as people change within their company.

The point that follows on from that is the issue of extensible/flexible APIs and no good way to handle SDKs and clients. Well, that's something we have planned a solution for. The existing client is terrible, and will be retired well before a 1.0 release or extensively reworked (ideally into the OpenStackSDK). We can easily have a consistent SDK for the non-pluggable sections of the API. For the remainder, the solution is two fold. Service side we refactor to have each pluggable API require a schema definition. The API would not function without it, we'd make that a hard requirement in code. The combination of the API schema, plus the changes to the internal task system will mean that we have a way of dynamically knowing what each API needs. We can then use that schema to build a capabilities API that returns exactly what a deployment of Adjutant is capable of and do so in a fashion so the SDK can make classes which build themselves around that returned data. This way we build an SDK and only need to do minor tweaks to it, or when we add non-pluggable APIs. This also means that any cloud writing their own Adjutant API is forced (by code) to define their API schema, which means that the custom API they build is entirely discoverable and the SDK just works with it.

Yes that's a lofty goal, we aren't there yet, but it's doable, and all the major internal service refactor work planned leads to it. The nature of Adjutant means that's the only kind of SDK that make sense.

But here's another view for that second point. fungi's comment in particular: "so instead you end up with provider-specific clients and sdks"
As the main dev behind Adjutant, and one that would end up having to write such a thing for our custom additions to Adjutant. I really really really don't want to. I don't have any intention to, and I think that's a terrible thing to do. Hence why I really want to make Adjutant (and its eventual SDK) just handle that automagically for me. I'm (like most devs) that odd kind of lazy that hates doing work that just makes no sense, wastes time, or could be automated. Provider specific SDKs for Adjutant are a waste of time, and I will do everything I can to avoid them ever being a thing. This is a hill I will probably die on if someone at Catalyst tells me we need a CatalystCloud specific SDK. 


The main drive behind Adjutant is pretty much exactly what mnaser said: "so the way i imagine adjutant is just a collaboration across different providers who would like to stop duplicating their logic and work together to implement their common business logic"
Which 'eventually' will leave us with a mostly consistent and generic set of APIs once we all actually start having a place to put them, and we figure out the overlap.


 > One question I had: what indications are there that other clouds
 > have adopted Adjutant or are likely to in future? Looking through
 > the logs there's no real outside commits since it was open sourced,
 > and there are no development discussions on openstack-dev. So far I
 > found:
 > 
 > * http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-operators/2017-June/013640.html
 > * https://bugs.launchpad.net/adjutant/+bug/1720756
 > * https://review.openstack.org/487823

As for other clouds using Adjutant, I only know of one cloud actually running it in prod and I don't know which features they have turned on other than password reset. The latter two of those links is from them (ELITS in Sweden). Nectar in Australia did express interest but there was no follow up, and our AU branch was sort of handling that. I think we just need to approach them again. There were two other companies that contacted us directly about information about it, and a research sector based private cloud, but I've heard from neither since. Then there are private clouds Catalyst will be helping deploy for some customers which might also end up using it. Plus there is 'general interest' from the public cloud working group, but I think most people are waiting for some semblance of official status and for the project to reach a little more maturity.

I'm also somewhat reluctant of pushing Adjutant right now until the major refactors planned are done. I don't expect to break anything in the existing APIs, but until we reach v1.0.0 I'm reserving the right to break something if we need to, and if we document the upgrade path. Should mostly be internal changes (config rework, policy, etc), rather than API changes.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-06-29 20:39:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> I'm also somewhat reluctant of pushing Adjutant right now until the major refactors planned are done.

I'd suggest that now is exactly the time you should be pushing other people to get involved, so that if it turns out you made any assumptions that are specific only to your own use case then you'll find out while they can still be changed."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-07-02 01:57:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> > I'm also somewhat reluctant of pushing Adjutant right now until
 > the major refactors planned are done.
 > 
 > I'd suggest that now is exactly the time you should be pushing
 > other people to get involved, so that if it turns out you made any
 > assumptions that are specific only to your own use case then you'll
 > find out while they can still be changed.

Involved yes, but the bit I worry about is outright adoption and use in prod only if they themselves aren't involved with dev, as otherwise they might not be aware of the potentially breaking changes between releases. Although even then provided people read the release notes (which we will start doing...), they should be safe enough.

That is exactly why official status at this fairly early stage would be great, since we'd get better visibility, more involvement, and that would mean we'd better steer the project in the right direction."}, {'account_id': 5638, 'date': '2018-07-03 18:07:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

+1 to what Sean said earlier - "I think there is value in this in being an official OpenStack project. I also think most of the concerns and objects have been (very patiently) answered and there is a good attitude from this team in making sure things are done right. I'm for it."

Hopefully the team understands the concerns and will poke the TC if it hits any of the grey areas mentioned in the long process. Adjutant team, Adrian, thanks for your patience.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-07-03 18:34:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

I think OpenStack is better off having this as a part of it than having it separate. I think it's likely that having some place to collaborate on common APIs, when the only other option is to have everyone implement these APIs independently, is going to help interoperability in a space where there is currently zero interoperability.

I don't think it's fair to ask them to try to diversify their contributor affiliation before they're admitted, since one of the main reasons projects seek to become official is exactly to gain visibility and thereby increase contributorship."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-07-05 10:14:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I can see the benefits and the downsides... At this point I'm a weak +1, but would rather not influence others by casting a final vote. We haven't heard from Emilien, Julia, Paul or Jeremy on this review yet.

Note that we are well past membership freeze so even if accepted today, Adjutant would not be part of the Rocky release, its first "official" release would be at Stein. We would of course give then space at the PTG in September if they needed some.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-07-05 19:20:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

To reiterate the concerns I expressed during our forum session on this, OpenStack has many past experiences with "dynamic" APIs. It's hard to build a user base around them as their opacity means there's no sane way to even document them much less support them in clients or SDKs. This ends up encouraging a proliferation of provider-specific instructions, utilities and libraries. In the projects where this has come up, dynamic elements of the API are invariably deprecated and removed or crystalized into a more static specification over time.

As the dynamism of its API seems integral to Adjutant's design, I worry that it will struggle to build a coherent community.'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-07-09 15:31:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

I've mostly sat on the sidelines on this topic, mostly to get a better understand from community and TC the pros and cons.  Right now, I'm in the positive side of accepting Adjutant, and with the points both Sean, Colleen and dims make, believe we can help do the right thing. With official status come the idea of more users and visibility hopefully this helps grow the project and ease some of the concerns raised."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-07-10 09:10:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

I've been on the fence about this because I've been trying to use this discussion as a foil in the larger discussion about what OpenStack is supposed to be. That hasn't worked as well as I would like, and with those discussions moving slowly I think it is unfair to linger.

And finally what cmurphy says with " I think it's likely that having some place to collaborate on common APIs, when the only other option is to have everyone implement these APIs independently, is going to help interoperability in a space where there is currently zero interoperability." is compelling. So...'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-07-10 16:07:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote-1 Code-Review+1

I've really struggled with this one. I've worked in the community with folks from Catalyst and they are wonderful contributors upstream who I know really get it.

That said, I'm uncomfortable with a project saying that we have to approve it as official before they will go out and actively try to get other groups involved, especially when it started as an internal thing and thus only one company has had any opportunity to have input into the use cases it's designed around. Nobody needs our permission to work together. This exact question came up during the TC election campaign, and I said that I'd be looking for projects that haven't been open from the beginning to demonstrate that they are, in fact, of interest to a wider audience, so I feel compelled to stick by that principle. I'm not willing to make an exception for a known good actor with a great reputation in the community (even though we want to encourage that) because I don't want to set a precedent that would lead to us publicly debating the open source bona fides of some other organisation in some future project application.

(I also apologise for not raising this issue earlier. I was distracted by the other stuff we had to work through and didn't investigate adoption/engagement from the wider community until late in the process.)

I *do* think it's completely reasonable to want to know whether the TC would *ever* accept an official project like this in principle when talking to potential adopters. So to be clear: I absolutely support Adjutant in principle and would vote for it if I had evidence that the built-in APIs are widely useful, and didn't have to rely on guesswork.

I understand the concerns other folks have expressed about interoperability, but I agree with Colleen's assessment that having any built-in standardised APIs is better than the zero standardisation we currently have. I'm not concerned that the underlying implementation is very flexible, and I don't see it as the TC's role to get projects to write their code more inflexibly. The change to the mission statement alleviates my earlier concerns that this could become a catch-all bucket for adding non-interoperable bits that should be addressed in an interoperable way in other parts of OpenStack, and I trust that the project team understand and respect the fact that they'd need to have another conversation with the TC before incorporating any in-tree APIs outside the scope agreed here.

Nevertheless, I'm very reluctantly voting No - or rather Not Yet. Since I'm a fan of actionable feedback, some examples of things that would help convince me that it's time:

* Discussions in the public cloud working group (or elsewhere) about the sufficiency or otherwise of the built-in APIs for a variety of use cases. If there's a PTG/Forum session I'd be happy to attend.
* Design discussions on the mailing list to resolve any points that come up.
* Evidence of testing, if not outright adoption, by other cloud operators and feedback therefrom (with follow-up where warranted).
* Existence of other implementations of back ends for the current API (not necessarily public, because it is tied in to internal business processes, but public acknowledgement of their existence would be useful).

Regardless of the outcome right now, I'd be happy to lend whatever limited expertise/influence I have to helping make that kind of stuff happen."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2018-07-11 07:05:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> That said, I'm uncomfortable with a project saying that we have to
 > approve it as official before they will go out and actively try to
 > get other groups involved, especially when it started as an
 > internal thing and thus only one company has had any opportunity to
 > have input into the use cases it's designed around. Nobody needs
 > our permission to work together. This exact question came up during
 > the TC election campaign, and I said that I'd be looking for
 > projects that haven't been open from the beginning to demonstrate
 > that they are, in fact, of interest to a wider audience, so I feel
 > compelled to stick by that principle. I'm not willing to make an
 > exception for a known good actor with a great reputation in the
 > community (even though we want to encourage that) because I don't
 > want to set a precedent that would lead to us publicly debating the
 > open source bona fides of some other organisation in some future
 > project application.

So I think part of this is coming from a comment I made earlier about why I'm a little reluctant of pushing Adjutant right now. That is mostly because right now I don't want to promote it as a finished solution. If anyone is going to get involved or use Adjutant right now, they should probably be prepared to work with us so we don't break them as we do some rather important refactors. We NEED other eyes on this project and its code, but not if they are expecting a magic black box that just 'works'. Adjutant isn't there yet.

That I didn't get across what I meant well is my fault. 

I have tried to get others involved, talked to various cloud providers, used to attend a lot of the early public cloud discussions, and was part of a  chunk of those during the Sydney summit.

In fact, Adjutant has solutions to, or alternatives to a bunch of the 'missing features' for public cloud:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Mf8OAyTzZxCKzYHMgBl-QK_2-XSycSkOjqCyMTIedkA/edit#gid=0

And even outside of public cloud it has uses and I keep running into similar things other people have written that Adjutant could do (or does).

The problem, no one seems to want to commit developers to help us make it better or fulfil their needs if it doesn't already. They kind of just want a magic black box that works without looking inside. Which is fine to an extent, but we're all about the opensource and collaboration! Yes Adjutant may end up at a point like that in future, but we need more eyes on the project, mode ideas and usecases covered before that.

We've had a reasonable amount of people express interest in the project, see that what it isn't a 'complete' solution, and then just move on. There are also people who probably would contribute if they knew about it, but getting word out about something like Adjutant isn't easy.

It's hard pushing a project as unglamorous as Adjutant. It's a service trying to solve possibly some of the most boring and pointlessly complicated business requirements, or add wrappers around things that otherwise work but not in a friendly way to users.

Adjutant did start as an internal thing (under a different name even), but it has been opensource in some fashion (on our github as StackTask) for a while before moving it to openstack's infrastructure. We always intended it to be opensource, and we always tried to design it to keep any Catalyst specific use cases out of the core codebase. It was fully opensource well before we ever deployed it to prod.

Could we push it harder? Yes, should we? Yes. But I'm the only one really doing that, and Adjutant isn't my only focus. Plus, Adjutant is hard to push both because it's hard to define (as this whole process is evident of), and because it really is unglamorous and targeted at ops/business rather than users. Compare this process to how easy getting Qinling (FaaS) approved and developers interested. That one also comes entirely from Catalyst, but aside from being a fantastic project, it's also a known quantity that is very glamorous and high profile due to its feature set (everyone knows what FaaS is).

While I agree that we could have done better, I just don't know how to market Adjutant. Maybe I need to add blockchain tech. :P


 > Nevertheless, I'm very reluctantly voting No - or rather Not Yet.
 > Since I'm a fan of actionable feedback, some examples of things
 > that would help convince me that it's time:
 > 
 > * Discussions in the public cloud working group (or elsewhere)
 > about the sufficiency or otherwise of the built-in APIs for a
 > variety of use cases. If there's a PTG/Forum session I'd be happy
 > to attend.
 > * Design discussions on the mailing list to resolve any points that
 > come up.
 > * Evidence of testing, if not outright adoption, by other cloud
 > operators and feedback therefrom (with follow-up where warranted).
 > * Existence of other implementations of back ends for the current
 > API (not necessarily public, because it is tied in to internal
 > business processes, but public acknowledgement of their existence
 > would be useful).
 > 
 > Regardless of the outcome right now, I'd be happy to lend whatever
 > limited expertise/influence I have to helping make that kind of
 > stuff happen.

I've been lax in attending the public cloud meetings (2-3am my time), so will send an email out to them and try and get someone from there to comment on this at least. There was interest from them for Adjutant, but it never really got anywhere with dev support or adoption other that from ELITS.

Also sort of related was a set of IRC discussions around ksproj:
https://github.com/CCI-MOC/ksproj
Which is yet another custom solution to a few things Adjutant already does, or at least in this specific case could do easily enough (our invite process doesn't work with federation but could easily enough). 

The fact that stuff like this keeps cropping up means there is most definitely a need. If knikolla had known about Adjutant he probably would have contributed rather than write ksproj, but raising Adjutant's profile is hard without some sort of official backing. If you have suggestions beyond what we've done, I'd be more than happy to try them!"}, {'account_id': 14495, 'date': '2018-07-12 04:13:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Adjutant serves very important, missing so far in the OpenStack ecosystem feature and I'd expect to TC recognise it as an official OpenStack project.
Hopefully this will also raise more interest from developers on Adjutant and allow to receive even more traction in the community."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-07-12 13:16:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

I'm a weak +1 on it. I have concerns, which I detailed in comments above and won't repeat here. But I think at this point we should go ahead and make Adjutant official now (for inclusion in the Stein release, since the release membership deadline for Rocky is now well-passed).

Regarding specifically the concerns around the usefulness of that project to others, I'm fine with a (small) leap of faith. Due to where the project will appear in the map and the lack of dependency from main services on Adjutant, it will be easier than most to remove if it goes nowhere (or in the wrong direction) in the future..."}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-07-13 14:52:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2018-07-13 14:55:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I'm a definite +1 on it as I believe it does solve a set of problems and cases which we have not solved well elsewhere. With that being said, I believe we need to be more inclusive of projects seeking to solve different but adjacent problems."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-13 15:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

The majority have voted in favor of this change, and it can be approved on or after 2018-07-14.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-07-16 13:36:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

To be clear, I remain unconvinced (in either direction) so am abstaining from this rollcall.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2018-07-16 13:58:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-17 17:40:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote-1

I am still reluctant to vote in favor of this project, based on the interoperability concerns I have expressed before. It seems the goal is to provide a framework to support deployer customization, rather than to provide a service that standardizes APIs for some of those common scenarios. Perhaps that is the right technical approach for that set of problems. I'm not convinced it is the right community approach."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-07-17 17:42:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow+1

This application is supported by the majority, so it is approved.

Because it is past the deadline for Rocky membership, Adjutant will not be considered part of the Rocky release, but a future release can be part of Stein. The team should complete the onboarding process for new projects, including holding PTL elections for Stein, setting up deliverable files in the openstack/releases repository, and adding meeting information to eavesdrop.openstack.org.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-16 00:52:32.000000000', 'message': 'Adjutant official project status

Adjuant is a service built to help manage certain elements of operations
processes by providing micro APIs around complex underlying workflow. It
started life as a system to manage sign ups to a public cloud, and grew into
a more generic and flexible system into which deployers can add useful APIs
for their users to consume.

The project history can be found on the docs[1], as well as some guide lines
which explain what the scope of the project is, and how we manage how vague it
is[2]. Then there is a section going over what is built into Adjutant[3].

The project was built to be integrated from the beginning with OpenStack, using
KeystoneMiddleware for auth, will be moving to oslo policy in the near
future, and we hope to switch to using the OpenStackSDK for all OpenStack API
interactions.

Adjutant meets all of the new project requirements easily. The source is Apache
License 2.0, and all libraries used are opensource. While the project was
started internally at Catalyst we use Launchpad for bug and blueprints tracking
and all of us are developers already working upstream with OpenStack. Code
review and gated testing is done on the OpenStack infrastructure, and the goal
is always to support features in other projects first (see guide-lines doc[2]).
We want to build Adjutant to be useful to the community and have taken care to
build ways to keep company specific logic out of the service by providing
plugin mechanisms.

Catalyst Cloud[4] is a company dedicated to opensource, and we always prefer
working with others to achieve a goal that works for everyone rather than
writing internal only solutions. Almost all our work is opensource where
applicable, and we are active in the community.

Catalyst Cloud runs Adjutant in production (very near to master), and we know
of at least another company using it for password resets, as well as interest
from a few more. For Catalyst Cloud it handles our full automated sign up
process, and we run almost all of the default Tasks as defined in the core
codebase for user management.

[1]: https://adjutant.readthedocs.io/en/latest/history.html
[2]: https://adjutant.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide-lines.html

'}, {'created': '2018-03-16 01:01:33.000000000', 'message': 'Adjutant official project status

Adjuant is a service built to help manage certain elements of operations
processes by providing micro APIs around complex underlying workflow. It
started life as a system to manage sign ups to a public cloud, and grew
into a more generic and flexible system into which deployers can add
useful APIs for their users to consume.

The project history can be found on the docs[1], as well as some guide
lines which explain what the scope of the project is, and how we manage
how vague it is[2]. Then there is a section going over what is built
into Adjutant[3].

The project was built to be integrated from the beginning with
OpenStack, using KeystoneMiddleware for auth, will be moving to oslo
policy in the near future, and we hope to switch to using the
OpenStackSDK for all OpenStack API interactions.

Adjutant meets all of the new project requirements easily. The source
is Apache License 2.0, and all libraries used are opensource. While the
project was started internally at Catalyst we use Launchpad for bug and
blueprints tracking and all of us are developers already working
upstream with OpenStack. Code review and gated testing is done on the
OpenStack infrastructure, and the goal is always to support features in
other projects first (see guide-lines doc[2]). We want to build Adjutant
to be useful to the community and have taken care to build ways to keep
company specific logic out of the service by providing plugin mechanisms.

Catalyst Cloud[4] is a company dedicated to opensource, and we always
prefer working with others to achieve a goal that works for everyone
rather than writing internal only solutions. Almost all our work is
opensource where applicable, and we are active in the community.

Catalyst Cloud runs Adjutant in production (very near to master), and we
know of at least another company using it for password resets, as well
as interest from a few more. For Catalyst Cloud it handles our full
automated sign up process, and we run almost all of the default Tasks as
defined in the core codebase for user management.

[1]: https://adjutant.readthedocs.io/en/latest/history.html
[2]: https://adjutant.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide-lines.html
[3]: https://adjutant.readthedocs.io/en/latest/features.html
[4]: https://catalystcloud.nz/

Change-Id: I0d119fa26b7ed8969870ad0c3f405e0ac3df98e3

commit_message:
Adjutant official project status

Adjuant is a service built to help manage certain elements of operations
processes by providing micro APIs around complex underlying workflow. It
started life as a system to manage sign ups to a public cloud, and grew
into a more generic and flexible system into which deployers can add
useful APIs for their users to consume.

The project history can be found on the docs[1], as well as some guide
lines which explain what the scope of the project is, and how we manage
how vague it is[2]. Then there is a section going over what is built
into Adjutant[3].

The project was built to be integrated from the beginning with
OpenStack, using KeystoneMiddleware for auth, will be moving to oslo
policy in the near future, and we hope to switch to using the
OpenStackSDK for all OpenStack API interactions.

Adjutant meets all of the new project requirements easily. The source
is Apache License 2.0, and all libraries used are opensource. While the
project was started internally at Catalyst we use Launchpad for bug and
blueprints tracking and all of us are developers already working
upstream with OpenStack. Code review and gated testing is done on the
OpenStack infrastructure, and the goal is always to support features in
other projects first (see guide-lines doc[2]). We want to build Adjutant
to be useful to the community and have taken care to build ways to keep
company specific logic out of the service by providing plugin mechanisms.

Catalyst Cloud[4] is a company dedicated to opensource, and we always
prefer working with others to achieve a goal that works for everyone
rather than writing internal only solutions. Almost all our work is
opensource where applicable, and we are active in the community.

Catalyst Cloud runs Adjutant in production (very near to master), and we
know of at least another company using it for password resets, as well
as interest from a few more. For Catalyst Cloud it handles our full
automated sign up process, and we run almost all of the default Tasks as
defined in the core codebase for user management.

[1]: https://adjutant.readthedocs.io/en/latest/history.html
[2]: https://adjutant.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide-lines.html
[3]: https://adjutant.readthedocs.io/en/latest/features.html
[4]: https://catalystcloud.nz/

Change-Id: I0d119fa26b7ed8969870ad0c3f405e0ac3df98e3

commit_message:
Add few more services to the inventory (nova, memcached)

- memcached is referenced in the configuration;
- nova-status seems to be unhappy if the placement API service
  is not enabled.

This scenario may work for now, but a proper Sahara deployment
requires more services (Neutron, Cinder, Glance, etc).
In order to run more advanced Sahara tests, both CLI and client
tempest.lib-based tests, and scenario tests, those services
will need to be added at some point.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/582627
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/582957
Change-Id: I9fdcdbc709a330d7ffec368e3d8dc43fb6276a24

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-12 18:27:19.000000000', 'message': "Execute service setup against a delegated host using Ansible built-in modules

In order to reduce the packages required to pip install on to the hosts,
we allow the service setup to be delegated to a specific host, defaulting
to the deploy host. We also switch as many tasks as possible to using the
built-in Ansible modules which make use of the shade library.

The 'virtualenv' package is now installed appropriately by the openstack_hosts
role, so there's no need to install it any more. The 'httplib2' package is a
legacy Ansible requirement for the get_url/get_uri module which is no longer
needed. The keystone client library is not required any more now that we're
using the upstream modules. As there are no required packages left, the task
to install them is also removed.

Change-Id: Ib4ff0ca76eb7b2ccaa373eeb1812e3d6741193fc
"}]
commit_message:
Execute service setup against a delegated host using Ansible built-in modules

In order to reduce the packages required to pip install on to the hosts,
we allow the service setup to be delegated to a specific host, defaulting
to the deploy host. We also switch as many tasks as possible to using the
built-in Ansible modules which make use of the shade library.

The 'virtualenv' package is now installed appropriately by the openstack_hosts
role, so there's no need to install it any more. The 'httplib2' package is a
legacy Ansible requirement for the get_url/get_uri module which is no longer
needed. The keystone client library is not required any more now that we're
using the upstream modules. As there are no required packages left, the task
to install them is also removed.

Change-Id: Ib4ff0ca76eb7b2ccaa373eeb1812e3d6741193fc

commit_message:
Request class-read object_prefix rbd_children perm

When using ceph as a backend request the additional privilege
class-read on rbd_children. This fixes bug 1696073.

Change-Id: I468cfb5026751b96feba013b4e6ae74ff8da38ca
Closes-Bug: #1696073

commit_message:
Fixup keystone endpoint handling

Finish the removal of creating an admin endpoint for keystone. This was
started in [0] but some fragments were still remaining.

At the same time the option to create an internal identity endpoint that
is different from the public one is reintroduced.

[0] I01d44e48053cad7aeb92636f4b41649204006c93

Change-Id: Id74966d9f1279f725bc41c08e434230a7845bbc1

commit_message:
Add octavia precreated image info

This commit adds how to set up a precreated amphora image for octavia on
the local.conf.sample. As diskimage-builder has been broken for a while
and it has been asked several times I think it's an useful info to have
on the sample file.

Change-Id: Ic14e1e98972dce0a33361fe589e331a2dcf65dfc
